0.0: MISHNAH: The Megillah is read on the eleventh, the twelfth, the thirteenth, the fourteenth, and the fifteenth [of Adar], never earlier and never later.
0.1: Cities which have been walled since the days of Yehoshua ben Nun read on the fifteenth. Villages and large towns read on the fourteenth. The villages, however may [sometimes] push the reading forward to the court day.
0.3: If [the fourteenth of Adar] falls on Monday, the villages and large towns read on that day, and the walled places on the next day.
0.4: If it falls on Tuesday or Wednesday, the villages push the reading forward to the court day. The large towns read on the day itself, and the walled place on the next day.
0.5: If [the fourteenth falls] on Thursday, the villages and large towns read on that day and the walled places on the next day.
0.6: If it falls on Friday, the villages push the reading forward to the court day, and the large towns and walled places read on the day itself.
0.7: If it falls on Shabbos, the villages and large towns push the reading [of the Megillah] forward to the court day and the walled places read [the Megillah] on the next day.
0.8: If it falls on Sunday, the villages push the reading [of the Megilla] forward to the court day. The large towns read on the same day, and the walled cities [read] on the following day.

10.22: 'Write this' [refers to] what is written here.  'Memorial' [refers to] what is written in Deuteronomy.  'In a book' [refers to] what is written in the Prophets.  [These are] the  words of Rabbi Yehoshua.
10.24: 'Write this' [refers to] what is written here and in Deuteronomy.  'Memorial' [refers to] what is written in the Prophets.  'In a book' [refers to] what is written in the Megillah.
10.25: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel:
10.26: [The scroll of] Esther does not defile the hands.
10.27: Is it to say that Shmuel avers that Esther was not composed with the Holy Spirit?
10.29: 'Esther was composed with the Holy Spirit?'
10.30: It was composed to be read, but not composed to be written.
10.33: Ecclesiastes does not defile the hands, and [opinion] is  divided concerning Song of Songs.
10.35: Song of Songs defiles the hands, and [opinion] is divided concerning Ecclesiastes.
10.37: Ecclesiastes is from the lenient [rulings] of Beit Shammai and the strict [rulings] of Beit Hillel, but Ruth, Song of Songs, and Esther do defile the hands.
10.38: He (Shmuel) said this in accordance with Rabbi Yehoshua.
10.39: It was taught:  Rabbi Shimon ben Menasia says:
10.40: Ecclesiastes does not defile the hands since it is just the wisdom of Solomon.
10.43: Has it not already been said (I Kings 5:12):  "And he spoke three thousand proverbs."?  It also says (Proverbs 30:6):  "Do not add onto his words."
10.46: The command he said is good, so if he desired he wrote, and if he did not desire he did not write.
10.47: Come and hear:  do not add onto his words.
10.48: Rabbi Eliezer taught in a Berayta
10.49: Esther was written through divine inspiration, as it says (Esther 6:6) "Haman said to himself."
10.51: Esther was written through divine inspiration, as it says (Esther 2:15) "Esther found favor in the eyes of all who saw her."
10.53: Esther was written through divine inspiration, as it says (Esther 2:22) "The matter became known to Mordechai."
10.55: Esther was composed with the Holy Spirit as is said (Esther 9:10):  "But they did not stretch out their hand toward the booty."
10.57: If I had been there, I would have made a statement preferable to all of them, as is said (Esther 9:27):  "They established and they accepted."  They established above that which they accepted below.
10.59: For all of them there is something objectionable in them except for that of Shmuel; in his there is nothing objectionable.
10.60: That of Rabbi Eliezer, his reasoning was that there was no person with whom the king agreed like [Haman], so that when he spoke expansively, he was thinking about himself as he spoke.
10.61: That of Rabbi Akiva:  perhaps like Rabbi Elazar, who said:
10.62: It teaches that to each and every person she was disguised as one of his own nation.
10.63: And that of Rabbi Meir:  perhaps like Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba, who said:
10.64: Bigtan and Teresh were two [men] of Tarsis.
10.65: And that of Rabbi Yose ben Durmaskit: perhaps soldiers were sent.
10.66: That of Shmuel:  sufficient and there is no objection in it.
10.68: It is the same as that which people say:
10.69: One pungent pepper is better than a basket full of melons.
10.71: (Esther 9:28):  "And these days of Purim will not pass by from the midst of the Jews."  Rav Nahman bar Yitzhak says from this:
10.72: "And their remembrance will not cease from their descendants."
10.75: (Esther 9:22)  "And sending portions, each to his neighbor."  [This means] two portions for one man.
10.76: (Esther 9:22)  "And gifts for the poor."  Two gifts for two persons.
10.77: Rabbi Yehuda Nesiah sent to Rabbi Oshaia the flank of a calf that was born third and a bottle of wine.  [Rabbi Oshaia] sent to him:

11.0: You have fulfilled with us, our Rabbi, [the commandment of] sending portions each to his neighbor and gifts for the poor.
11.1: Rabbah sent to Mari bar Mar through Abaye a basket filled with dates and a full cup of the flour of dried grain.
11.4: If a peasant becomes the king, he does not set down the bowl from his neck.
11.5: He sent back to him a basket filled with ginger and a full cup of long peppers.
11.8: I sent to him something sweet and he sent back to me [something] pungent.
11.10: When I went out of Master's house, I was sated. When I arrived there, they brought me sixty plates of sixty types of food and I ate sixty portions of them.
11.11: And the last dish they called 'pot roast' and afterward I wanted to chew the plate.
11.14: 'A poor person is hungry and does not know it.'
11.17: Abaye bar Avin and Rabbi Hanina bar Avin used to exchange their meals with each other.
11.19: A man is obligated to mellow oneself [get drunk] until he does not know the difference between 'cursed is Haman' and 'Blessed is Mordechai.'
11.20: Raba and Rabi Zeira made a Seudat Purim together. They became mellowed and then Raba arose and slaughtered Rabi Zeira.
11.21: The next day he prayed for [divine] mercy and he returned to life.
11.22: The next year, he [Raba] said to him [Rabi Zeira]
11.23: "Come and let us make a seudat purim together."
11.25: "Not every single time does a miracle occur."
11.27: [If] one eats a Purim feast at night, he has not fulfilled his obligation.  What is the reason?  It is written (Esther 9:22):  "Days of banquets and rejoicing."
11.28: Rav Ashi was sitting before (Rav Kahana).  It grew late and the Rabbis had not come.
11.30: What is the reason the Rabbis have not come?
11.31: Perhaps they are busily engaged with a Purim feast?  He said to him:
11.32: Is it not possible to eat [the feast] at night?
11.34: Did Master not hear what Rava said?
11.35: A Purim feast that is eaten at night does not fulfill his obligation.
11.40: He repeated [the saying] forty times after him until he had put it in his 'pouch' (memory).
11.41: Mishnah.  There is no difference between a festival (yom tov) and Shabbat except [regarding] food preparation.
11.42: Gemara.  But on the subject of ancillaries for food preparation, this (festival) and that (Shabbat) are equal.
11.43: The Mishnah does not follow Rabbi Yehudah.  For it was taught:
11.44: There is no difference between a festival and Shabbat, except food preparation.  Rabbi Yehudah permits even ancillaries for food preparation.
11.45: What is the reason that the First Tanna?  Scripture says (Exodus 12:16):  "that".  But not 'ancillaries'.
11.47: (Exodus 12:16) "for you".  'For you' [means] all that is necessary for you.
11.48: Isn't it written 'for you' for the other one also?
11.49: [He could answer]:  For you and not for star worshipers; for you and not for dogs.
11.50: But isn't it written 'that' for the other one also?
11.51: 'That' is written and 'for you' is written.  Here it is with the ancillaries that are possible to do the day before a festival.  There it is with ancillaries that are not possible to do the day before a festival.
11.52: Mishnah.  There is no difference between Shabbat and Yom Kippur except for this one (Shabbat) a premeditated violation [is punished] by human hands, and for that one (Yom Kippur) a premeditated violation [is punished] by Karet ("cutting off" by a 'divine court').
11.53: Gemara.  But on the subject of compensation, this one and that one are equal.
11.54: Whose Mishnah [is this]?  It is by Rabbi Nehunia ben Hakanah.
11.55: For it was taught:  Rabbi Nehunia ben Hakanah was doing Yom Kippur like Shabbat regarding compensation.
11.56: One who [violates] Shabbat will pay with his life but is exempt from compensation; also on Yom Kippur one pays with his life but is exempt from compensation.
11.58: All whose penalty is Karet who were punished by lashes are exempt from the penalty of Karet, as is said (Deuteronomy 25:3):  "...and your brother will be lashed before your eyes."  As soon as he has been lashed, behold, he is like your brother.  [These are] the words of Rabbi Hanania ben Gamliel.
11.60: The colleagues of Rabbi Hanania ben Gamliel disagreed with him [in this matter].
11.62: They said in the school of Rav:
11.63: We learned that there is no difference between Yom Kipper and Shabbat except that for this one a premeditated violation [is punished] by human hands and for that one a premeditated violation [is punished] by Karet.
11.64: But if this is so, this one and that one are [both punished] by human hands.
11.66: Whose opinion is this?  It is Rabbi Yitzhak, who said:
11.67: Lashes are not a payment for Karet.
11.68: As was taught:  Rabbi Yitzhak says:
11.69: Those who owe Karet are part of the general principle.  Why is Karet brought out [specially in the case of lying] with his sister?  To judge with Karet and not lashes.
11.71: You can even say that the Rabbis [concur].  For this one, the chief [punishment for] a premeditated violation is in human hands, and for that one, the chief [punishment for] a premeditated violation is with Karet.

12.0: Mishnah.  There is no difference between one who is prohibited by a vow from benefiting from his fellow and one who is prohibited by a vow from [benefiting] from his food, except for setting foot [on his property] and utensils that a person does not use for [preparing] food.
12.1: Gemara.  But regarding utensils with which a person prepares food, this one and that one are equal.
12.2: 'Setting foot': But people are not sensitive [about others setting foot on their property].
12.4: Whose opinion is this?  Rabbi Eliezer, who said:
12.5: Customary benefits are prohibited to one who is prohibited by a vow from any benefit.
12.6: Mishnah.  There is no difference between vow-offerings and generosity-offerings except that vow-offerings obligate one with [providing] surety (for the vowed animal), but generosity-offerings do not obligate one with surety.
12.7: Gemara.  But regarding not delaying, this one and that one are equal.
12.9: What is a vow-offering?  One who says, 'behold, I am raising up a burnt (olah) offering'.
12.10: What is a generosity-offering?  One who says, 'behold, this one is a burnt offering'.
12.11: And what is [the difference] between vow-offerings and generosity-offerings?
12.12: Vow-offerings that die or are stolen or are lost obligate [one to provide] surety (to provide a substitute).  Generosity-offerings that die or are stolen or are lost do not obligate [one to provide] surety.  From where is this thing?
12.14: (Leviticus 1:4)  "And it will be accepted for him to atone upon him."  Rabbi Shimon says:
12.15: That which is 'upon him' obligates him for surety.  That which is not upon him does not obligate him for surety.
12.18: Since he said 'upon me', which is like he was carrying it upon his shoulder.
12.19: Mishnah.  There is no difference between a zav who sees two discharges and one who sees three except an offering.  (A zav is a male who experiences a genital discharge of something other than semen.  -- trans.)
12.20: Gemara.  But regarding [the defilement of] a couch or a seat and counting seven days, this one and that one are equal.
12.24: That which is written (Leviticus 15:2) counted two [discharges] and they called [the zav] 'unclean'.  (Leviticus 15:3) Three and they called [the zav] 'unclean'.
12.26: Two [discharges] to be unclean and three to bring an offering.
12.27: Now, say two [discharges] to be unclean and not bring an offering; three to bring an offering but not to be unclean.
12.29: before, he did not see three, he saw [only] two, and say
12.30: two to bring an offering and not to be unclean, then three to be unclean.
12.31: Do not let this rise up in your mind, for it was taught:
12.32: (Leviticus 15:15):  "The priest shall atone for him before Hashem from his discharge."  In some cases, zavs bring an offering and in some cases zavs do not bring an offering.
12.34: [If] he saw three [discharges] he brings [an offering], [only] two and he does not bring.
12.36: he saw two [so] he brings [an offering]; he saw three [so] he does not bring.
12.38: before, he did not see three, he saw [only] two.
12.39: [The saying of] Rabbi Simai is necessary, and 'from his discharge' is necessary.
12.40: For if, from [the saying of] Rabbi Simai I might have stated an objection.  Therefore, we learn from 'from his discharge'.
12.41: And if, with 'from his discharge', I would not understand how many sightings [of discharge].  We learn this from Rabbi Simai.
12.42: And now that you have said 'from his discharge' is to be expounded, (Leviticus 15:13):  "When the zav has been cleansed from his discharge..."  How do you expound it?
12.43: That one is required for that which was taught:
12.44: And 'when the zav has been cleansed' for when his discharge has ended.  ['From his discharge'], and not from [both] his discharge and his leprosy (tzaraat).
12.45: "From his discharge he shall count" (Leviticus 15:13):  This teaches about the zav who sees two [discharges], so that he requires a count of seven [days].
12.47: If he defiles a couch or a seat, is he not required to count seven [days]?

13.0: [That a woman] observes a day corresponding to a day is evidence that defilement of a couch or seat does not require counting seven [days].
13.1: So then you should not be astonished about this, that even though he defiles a couch or a seat he is not required to count seven [days].  The teaching says "from his discharge he shall count".  In some cases, 'from his discharge he shall count' teaches about the zav who sees two [discharges], that he is required to count seven [days].
13.3: What changes this 'from his discharge' that it includes 'a zav who sees two [discharges]'?  And what changes this 'from his discharge' that it excludes 'a zav who sees two [discharges]'?
13.5: If your mind reasons that this is to exclude that expression, a verse would be silent about it.
13.6: And then you will say that this brings in the decision '[a woman who] observes a day corresponding to a day is evidence.
13.8: This one is required for 'from his discharge' and not for leprosy.  If so, let the verse write:  "And when the zav has been cleansed", then remain silent.  Why do I have 'from his discharge'?
13.9: It teaches about the zav who sees two [discharges], that he is required to count [seven].
13.10: Mishnah.  There is no difference between a potential leper and a confirmed leper except letting one's hair grow and rending a garment.
13.11: There is no difference between one cleansed from potential [leprosy] and one cleansed from confirmed [leprosy] except shaving and [offering] birds.
13.12: Gemara.  But regarding being sent out [from the camp] [and defilement] this one and that one are equal.
13.14: As Rav Shmuel bar Yitzhak taught standing near Rav Huna:
13.15: (Leviticus 13:6):  "And the priest will pronounce him clean, it is a sore (other than leprosy); and he shall wash his clothes, and he is clean."  He was clean from the start regarding letting hair grow and rending a garment.
13.17: But according to this, regarding a zav it is written (Leviticus 15:13):  "And he shall wash his clothes and be clean."  In that case, what does 'clean from the start' [mean] here?
13.19: He is cleansed now from defiling earthenware vessels by shaking them.  Even if he sees another [discharge], he does not defile retroactively.  Here also, [the leper] is cleansed [now from defiling by coming in retroactively].
13.21: From here (Leviticus 13:45):  "And the leper in whom the affliction rests...", [which means] the one whose leprosy is contingent on his body rather than on days.  This excludes one whose leprosy is not contingent on his body, but on days.
13.23: But according to this, (Leviticus 13:46):  "All the days that there is an affliction in him he is defiled" [means that] one whose leprosy is contingent on his body is the one who is required to be sent out.  One whose leprosy is not contingent on his body is not required to be sent out.
13.24: And thus you may say that here also.  However, it was taught:
13.25: There is no difference between a potential leper and a confirmed leper except letting hair grow and rending a garment.  But regarding sending out and defiling by coming in, this one and that one are equal.
13.27: 'The days' [means] 'all the days'.  [This] includes a potential leper being sent out.
13.28: If so, what is the reason for not shaving or [offering] birds?
13.30: There is no difference between being cleansed from potential [leprosy] and being cleansed from confirmed [leprosy] except shaving and [offering] birds.
13.32: A verse (Leviticus 14:3) says:  "The priest will go out to the outside of the camp, ... and behold, the affliction of the leper has been healed."  [This means] one whose leprosy is contingent on healing.  This excludes one whose leprosy is not contingent on healing, but on days.
13.33: Mishnah.  There is no difference between scrolls, tefillin, and mezuzahs except that scrolls may be written in any language, while tefillin and mezuzahs may not be written [in anything] but Assyrian script (i.e., Hebrew).  (Assyrian script is the familiar Hebrew square character script.  -- trans.)
13.35: Even with scrolls, they did not permit that they be written [in any foreign language] but Greek.
13.36: Gemara.  But [regarding] sewing with sinews and defiling the hands, this one and that one are equal.
13.37: 'But scrolls may be written in any language', etc.
13.39: Hebrew text that is written in Aramaic, or Aramaic text that is written in Hebrew, or if one wrote in [old] Hebrew [script]:  there is no defilement of the hands until one writes it in Assyrian script upon a scroll with ink.

14.0: Here it is in our characters.  There it is in their characters.
14.2: Why did you raise up 'in their characters'?  Why argue about Hebrew that is written in Aramaic or Aramaic that is written in Hebrew?
14.3: Even Hebrew that is written in Hebrew and Aramaic that is written in Aramaic also [are not valid].  For it is taught there [that there is no defilement] 'until one writes it in Assyrian script upon a scroll in ink'.
14.5: This [teaching] is by the Rabbis; that [teaching] is by Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.
14.6: If this is [the teaching of] Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, there is Greek.
14.8: Here [we are dealing] with scrolls [of Scripture], there [we are dealing] with tefillin and mezuzahs.
14.9: What is the reason [for] tefillin and mezuzahs?  Because of that which is written in it (Deuteronomy 6:6):  "...and they shall be...", [which means that] they must be original.  What [cases] are there about Aramaic that has been written in Hebrew?
14.10: Certainly, there is [Aramaic in the] Torah (Genesis 31:47):  "Hill of Testimony" (Yegar Sahaduta).
14.11: But here [in the case of tefillin and mezuzahs], what Aramaic is there?
14.13: Here [we are dealing] with the Megillah, there [we are dealing] with scrolls [of Scripture].
14.14: What is the reason [for] the Megillah?  that which is written in it (Esther 8:9):  "According to their writing and according to their language."  What [cases] of Aramaic that has been written in Hebrew are there?
14.16: (Esther 1:20):  "And the 'decree' of the king shall be heard."  Rav Nachman bar Yitzhak said:
14.17: (Esther 1:20):  "And all of the women shall give 'honor' to their husbands."
14.19: This was taught concerning the remaining scrolls [of scripture].  And that is from Rabbi Yehudah.
14.21: Tefillin and mezuzahs may not be written in anything but Assyrian script, but our Rabbis permitted Greek.
14.22: But it is written:  "And they shall be".
14.24: scrolls may be written in any language, and our Rabbis permitted Greek.
14.26: This implies that the First Kamma prohibited [Greek].
14.28: our Rabbis did not permit that they be written in anything but Greek.
14.29: And it was taught:  Rabbi Yehudah said:
14.30: Even when our Rabbis permitted Greek, they did not permit [it for] anything but a Torah scroll, because of the case of Ptolemy the King.
14.32: [This is] the case of Ptolemy the King, who gathered seventy-two elders and entered them into seventy-two houses, and he did not reveal to them for what he gathered them.
14.33: He then met each of them individually and he said to them:
14.34: "Write for me the Torah of Moses your teacher [in Greek]."
14.35: The Holy One, Blessed Be He put counsel into the heart of each one, and all of them harmonized to one understanding.
14.36: And they wrote for him:  "God created in the beginning." (Genesis 1:1)  "I shall make a human in image and likeness." (Genesis 1:26)  "And He finished on the sixth day, and He rested on the seventh day." (Genesis 2:2)   "Male and female He created him, and they did not write 'He created them'." (Genesis 5:2)  "Come, let Me descend and confound their language there." (Genesis 11:7)  "And Sarah laughed among her relatives." (Genesis 18:12)  "For in their anger they killed an ox, and in their desire they uprooted a manger."  (Genesis 49:6)  "And Moses took his wife and his sons and had them ride on a 'carrier of humans'". (Exodus 4:20)  "And the settlement of the children of Israel, in which they dwelled in Egypt and in other lands, was four hundred years." (Exodus 12:40)  "And he sent the youths of the children of Israel." (Exodus 24:5)  "And against the youths of the children of Israel He did not stretch out His hand."  (Exodus 24:11)

15.0: (Numbers 16:15) "I have not taken one desired thing of theirs."  (Deuteronomy 4:19)  "Which Hashem your God has apportioned them, to be a light unto all the peoples."  (Deuteronomy 17:3)  "And he went and he served other gods which I did not command that they should be served."  They wrote for him:  "with small legs".  And they did not write for him (Leviticus 11:6)  "and the hare" because the name of Ptolemy's wife was Arnevet (hare).  Therefore, he could not say:
15.1: 'The Jews taunted me and they put the name of my wife into the Torah.'
15.2: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says that even scrolls [of Scripture] are not permitted to be written in anything but Greek.
15.3: Rabbi Abahu said in the name of Rabbi Yohanan:
15.4: Halakhah follows Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.
15.6: What is Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel's reason?  A verse says (Genesis 9:27):  "God will widen Japheth and he will tent in the tents of Shem."  [This means that] the words of Japheth will be in the tents of Shem.
15.7: Then [should we] say:  Gomer and Magog?
15.9: This is our reason:  for it is written:  "God will widen (yaft) the tents of Japheth (Yefet)."  The beauty (yafyuto) of Japheth (Yefet) will be in the tents of Shem.
15.10: Mishnah.  There is no difference between a priest anointed with the oil of anointing and one [invested] through additional garments except the bull which comes for all of the commandments.
15.11: There is no difference between a serving [high] priest and a former [high] priest except a bull for Yom Kippur and the tenth of an ephah.
15.12: Gemara.  But regarding a bull for Yom Kippur and the tenth of an ephah, this one and that one are equal.
15.13: Our Mishnah does not follow Rabbi Meir.  For if it followed Rabbi Meir, [there is this [contradicting] teaching]:
15.14: [A priest invested] through additional garments brings a bull, which comes for all of the commandments -- the words of Rabbi Meir.
15.17: What is Rabbi Meir's reason?  For it was taught:
15.18: (Leviticus 4:3) "Anointed".  I have no [explanation] but 'anointed with the oil of anointing'.  From where is 'through additional garments'?
15.20: How has it been established?  That it is not like Rabbi Meir.
15.21: Say about the end [of the Mishnah]:
15.22: There is no difference between a serving [high] priest and a former priest except a bull for Yom Kippur and the tenth of a ephah.  But regarding all of their other things, this one and that one are equal.
15.23: We come to [the teaching of] Rabbi Meir, as was taught:
15.24: [If] an invalidation befalls [the high priest], and they appointed another priest [to serve] in his place, [when] the first one returns to his service, the second [still has] all of the commandments of the high priesthood upon him -- the words of Rabbi Meir.
15.26: [When] the first one returns to his service, the second one is no longer fit to be either high priest or a common priest.
15.28: It happened with Rabbi Yosef ben Ulam of Tzippori, that an invalidation befell the high priest and they appointed him (Rabbi Yosef) in his place.  Then the case came before the Sages, and they said:
15.29: The first one returns to his service [and] the second one is no longer fit to be either high priest or a common priest.
15.30: 'High priest' because of enmity; 'common priest' because with sacred [matters], we raise up but we do not lower.
15.31: The beginning is [the opinion of] the Rabbis and the ending is Rabbi Meir's?
15.33: Yes.  The beginning is the Rabbis and the ending is Rabbi Meir.
15.35: It is from Rabbi (Judah HaNasi), who takes it from the opinion of the Tannaim.
15.36: Mishnah.  There is no difference between a large high place and a small high place except passover offerings.
15.38: Anything that is a vow-offering or a generosity-offering may be offered at a [small] high place, and anything that is neither a vow-offering nor a generosity-offering may not be offered at a [small] high place.
15.39: Gemara.  The passover offerings and nothing else?
15.44: For it was taught:  Rabbi Shimon says:
15.45: Even the public did not offer anything but passover offerings and obligatory offerings for which a time is fixed.  But obligatory offerings for which a time is not fixed were not offered either here or there.
15.46: Mishnah.  There is no difference between Shiloh and Jerusalem except that in Shiloh one may eat 'light' sanctified food and the second tithe anywhere one can see [the Tabernacle], but in Jerusalem [they may be eaten only] within the wall.
15.47: Both here and there the 'most sanctified' food may [only] be eaten within the curtains.

16.0: there was legal permission after it [was destroyed].
16.1: [As to] the sanctity of Jerusalem, there was no legal permission after it [was destroyed].
16.3: I heard that one may bring offerings in the house of Honyo at this time.
16.5: the house of Honyo is not a house of idol service, and he also avers that
16.6: the first sanctification [of Jerusalem] sanctified it for its hour, but did not sanctify it for future time.
16.7: For it is written (Deuteronomy 12:9):  "Because you have not yet come to the resting place and to the inheritance."  'Resting place' is Shiloh; 'inheritance' is Jerusalem.
16.9: Just as there is legal permission after 'resting place', so there is legal permission after 'inheritance'.
16.15: He said it and I learned it from him.
16.16: Then what is the reason he retracted it?
16.17: Because of the difficulty of Rav Mari.
16.19: [Regarding the] sanctity of Shiloh, there is legal permission after it; [but with] the sanctity of Jerusalem, there is no legal permission after it.
16.21: From [the time] that they came to Jerusalem 'high places' (bamot) were prohibited, and there was no longer legal permission for them.  And it was the 'inheritance'.
16.24: I heard that as they were building the Holy Place they made curtains for the Holy Place and curtains for the enclosure.
16.25: But with the Holy Place they built [the wall] on the outside [of the curtains] and with the enclosure they built on the inside.
16.27: I heard that we may bring offerings even though there is no Temple, and [priests] may eat the Holy of Holies even though there are no curtains.  [Foods of] 'light' sanctity and the second tithe [may be eaten] even though there is no wall.
16.28: Because the first sanctification [of Jerusalem] sanctified it for its hour, and sanctified it for future time.
16.29: By implication, then Rabbi Eliezer avers that
16.30: [the first sanctification] did not sanctify it for future time.
16.33: Perhaps for the entire world the first sanctification sanctified it for its hour and sanctified it for future time.
16.34: So [one] Master said what he had heard and [the other] Master said what he had heard.
16.35: So if you say, why 'curtains' according to Rabbi Eliezer, [we say] merely for privacy.
16.36: Rather, it is because of these Tannaim:
16.37: For it was taught:  Rabbi Yishmael the son of Rabbi Yose said:
16.38: Why did the Sages count these [cities]?
16.39: Because when the exiles ascended [back to Israel] they found these [walled cities] and they sanctified them.  But [the sanctity of] the first [cities] was annulled when [the sanctity of] the land was annulled.
16.41: the first sanctification sanctified it for its hour but did not sanctify it for future time.
16.42: But there is a contradiction.  Rabbi Yishmael son of Rabbi Yose said:
16.44: But hasn't it already been said (Deuteronomy 3:4):  "Sixty cities, the entire boundary of Argov"?  And it is written (Deuteronomy 3:5):  "All of these were fortified cities with a high wall."  So, why did the Sages count [only] these?
16.45: Because when the exiles ascended [back to Israel] they found these [walled cities] and they sanctified them.

17.0: Now, it is said that there is no need to sanctify!
17.2: they found these and they counted them.
17.3: And not these alone, but all for which you can obtain a tradition from your ancestors that they were surrounded by a wall in the days of Joshua bin Nun.  All of the commandments apply in it, because the first sanctification sanctified [it] for its hour and sanctified it for future time.
17.4: There is a difficulty between [one opinion of] Rabbi Yishmael and [another opinion of] Rabbi Yishmael.
17.5: Two Tannaim view the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael son of Rabbi Yose differently.
17.6: And if you prefer, you may say:
17.7: This one was said by Rabbi Elazar bar Yose,
17.8: as was taught:  Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Yose said:
17.9: (Leviticus 25:30):  "...which does (not) have a wall...".  Even though it does not have one now, it had one earlier.
17.10: "And it came to pass in the days of Ahashverosh."
17.11: Rabbi Levi said -- and some say it was Rabbi Yonatan:
17.12: This saying is a tradition placed in our hands by the Men of the Great Assembly:
17.13: Any place [in Scripture] that says 'And it came to pass' (Vayahi) is nothing but an expression of trouble.
17.14: (Esther 1:1) "And it came to pass in the days of Ahashverosh":  there was Haman.  (Ruth 1:1) "And it came to pass in the days in which the Judges judged":  there was a famine.  (Genesis 6:1) "And it came to pass that humans began to increase...":  'Hashem saw that the wickedness of humans was great'.
17.15: (Genesis 11:2) "And it came to pass as they traveled from the east":  'Come, let us build a city for ourselves'.
17.16: (Genesis 14:1) "And it came to pass in the days of Amrafel":  they made war.
17.17: (Joshua 5:13) "And it came to pass when Joshua was in Jericho": 'and his sword was drawn in his hand'.
17.18: (Joshua 6:27) "And it came to pass that Hashem was with Joshua":  The Children of Israel circumvented [the herem].
17.19: (I Samuel 1:1) "And it came to pass that there was one man from Ramathaim":  'for he loved Hannah, but Hashem had closed her womb'.
17.20: (I Samuel 8:1) "And it came to pass (when) Samuel was old":  'his sons did not walk in his ways'.
17.21: (I Samuel 18:14) "And it came to pass that David succeeded in all of his ways [and Hashem was with him]":  'and it came to pass that Saul eyed David'.
17.22: (II Samuel 7:1) "And it came to pass that the king dwelled in his house":  'only you will not build the house (Temple)'.
17.23: But it is written (Leviticus 9:1):  "And it came to pass on the eighth day", and it has been taught:
17.24: On that day there was rejoicing before the Holy One, Blessed Be He, as on the day on which heaven and earth were created.  It is written here 'and it came to pass on the eighth day' and it is written there (Genesis 1:5):  "And it came to pass that [it was evening and it was] (morning), one day."
17.26: And it is written (I Kings 6:1):  "And it came to pass in the four hundred eightieth year."
17.27: And it is written (Genesis 29:10):  "And it came to pass when Jacob saw Rachel."
17.28: And it is written:  "And it came to pass that it was evening and it was morning, one day."
17.29: And there is 'the second' and there is 'the third' and there are many [other cases].
17.31: For all [cases of] 'and it came to pass', there are [good] and there are [bad].
17.32: But 'and it came to pass in the days of...' is nothing but an expression of trouble.
17.33: There are five [occurrences of] 'and it came to pass in the days of...'.
17.34: 'And it came to pass in the days of Ahashverosh.'  'And it came to pass in the days in which Judges judged.'  'And it came to pass in the days of Amrafel.'  (Isaiah 7:1):  'And it came to pass in the days of Ahaz.'  (Jeremiah 1:3):  'And it came to pass in the days of Yehoiakim.'
17.36: This saying is a tradition placed in our hands by our ancestors:
17.39: That this is what Rabbi Shmuel bar Nahmani said in the name of Rabbi Yonatan:
17.40: Every bride who is discreet in the house of her father-in-law will merit having kings and prophets come forth from her.
17.41: How do we know?  From Tamar,
17.42: for it is written (Genesis 38:15):  "Judah saw her and thought her to be a prostitute because she had covered her face."
17.43: Because she had covered her face he thought her to be a prostitute?
17.45: because she covered her face in the house of her father-in-law and he did not know her [appearance], she merited having kings and prophets come forth [from her].
17.46: Kings from David.  Prophets, as Rabbi Levi had said,
17.47: [from] a tradition placed in our hands by our ancestors.
17.49: And it is written (Isaiah 1:1):  "A vision of Isaiah son of Amoz."
17.51: This saying is a tradition placed in our hands by our ancestors:
17.52: There was no measurement for the space of the Ark.
17.54: The Ark that Moses made had [a space of] ten cubits on each side.  And it is written (I Kings 6:20):  "And in front of the Holy of Holies was twenty cubits in length..."  And it is written:  "The wing of one cherub was ten cubits and the wing of the other cherub was ten cubits."  Where was the Ark itself standing?
17.55: Rather, learn from this that there is no [space]
17.56: in the miracle of its standing.
17.57: Rabbi Yonaton took his opening text for this lesson (parasha) from here:
17.58: (Isaiah 14:22):  "I will rise up against them, etc. and I will cut off from Babylon name and remnant and child and offspring, says Hashem."
17.59: 'Name', this is script; 'remnant', this is language; 'child', this is kingdom; 'offspring', this is Vashti.
17.60: Rabbi Shmuel bar Nahmani took his opening text for this lesson from here:
17.61: (Isaiah 55:13):  "Instead of the thorn a cypress shall come up, and instead of the brier a myrtle shall come up."
17.62: 'Instead of the thorn':  instead of the wicked Haman who made himself into an object of worship.  As it is written (Isaiah 7:19):  "Upon all the thorns and upon all the branches."  'A cypress shall come up', this is Mordechai, who was called chief among all of the spices, as is said (Exodus 30:23):  "and you, take for yourself the chief spices, flowing myrrh...".  We translate (into Aramaic)
17.64: 'Instead of the brier':  instead of the wicked Vashti, daughter of the son of the wicked Nebuchadnezzar, who burned the pillar of the House of Hashem.  As it is written (Song of Songs 3:10):  "His pillar was gold."  'A myrtle (hadas) shall come up', this Esther the righteous, who was called Hadassah, as is said (Esther 2:7):  "And he brought up Hadassah."
17.65: 'And it shall be to Hashem for a name', this is the reading of the Megillah.  'For an everlasting sign that will not be cut off', these are the days of Purim.
17.66: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi took his opening text for this lesson from here:
17.67: (Deuteronomy 28:63):  "And it shall be, as Hashem rejoiced over you to do good with you, thus he will rejoice to do bad with you."  (Text of Gemara does not agree with Torah.  -- trans.)
17.68: Does the Holy One, Blessed Be He, rejoice in the downfall of the wicked?
17.69: But it is written (II Chronicles 20:21):  "In going out before the army, they said thanks to Hashem that His kindness is forever."  And Rabbi Yohanan said:
17.70: Why is 'because He is good' not said with this thanksgiving?  This is because the Holy One, Blessed Be He, does not rejoice at the downfall of the wicked.
17.72: Why has it been written (Exodus 14:20):  "This one did not draw near to that one the whole night."?  The ministering angels sought to recite a song, [but] the Holy One, Blessed Be He said:
17.73: The work of My hands is drowning in the sea, and you are reciting a song???
17.75: He does not rejoice, but He causes others to rejoice.
17.76: Also, it is written precisely as 'He will cause to rejoice' (yasis); it is not written 'He rejoices' (yasus).  Learn from this.
17.77: Rabbi Abba bar Kahana took his opening text for this lesson from here:
17.78: (Ecclesiastes 2:26):  "For a human who is good before Him, he has given wisdom and knowledge and happiness."  This is Mordechai the righteous.  But to a sinner he has given the object of gathering and collecting.  This is Haman.  To give to the one who is good before God; this is Mordechai and Esther.  As is written:
17.79: "And Esther placed Mordechai in charge of Haman's house."
17.80: Rabbah bar Ofran took his opening text for this lesson from here:
17.81: (Jeremiah 49:38):  "I will place my throne in Elam and I will cause king and princes to perish from there."
17.82: 'King', this is Vashti.  'Princes', this is Haman and his ten sons.
17.83: Rav Dimi bar Yitzhak took his opening text for this lesson from here:

18.0: (Ezra 9:9):  "For we are servants, but God does not abandon us in our servitude; and He has extended kindness upon us before the kings of Persia."  When?  In the time of Haman.
18.1: Rabbi Hanina bar Papa  took his opening text for this lesson from here:
18.2: (Psalms 66:12) "You have caused a man to ride above our head, we came through fire and water."
18.3: 'Through fire' in the days of Nebuchadnezzar the wicked one, and 'through water' in the days of Pharaoh.
18.4: "And you brought us out into abundance" in the days of Haman.
18.5: Rabbi Yohanan  took his opening text for this lesson from here:
18.6: (Psalms 98:3) "He remembers His kindness and His faithfulness toward the House of Israel, and all the ends of the earth have seen the salvation of our God."  When did 'all the ends of the earth see the salvation of our God'?  In the days of Mordechai and Esther.
18.7: Reish Lakish  took his opening text for this lesson from here:
18.8: (Proverbs 28:15) "[As] a roaring lion and a roving bear, [so] is a wicked one who rules over a poor people."
18.9: 'A roaring lion', this is Nebuchadnezzar the wicked one, of whom it is written (Jeremiah 4:7):  "A lion has ascended from his thicket."  'A roving bear', this is Ahashverosh, of whom it is written (Daniel 7:5):  "And behold!  another beast, a second one, like a bear."
18.11: These are Persians who eat and drink like a bear, are covered with flesh like a bear, and grow hair like a bear, and they, like a bear, do not rest.
18.12: 'A wicked one who rules', this is Haman.  'Over a poor people', this is Israel, who are poor in [observance of] commandments.
18.13: Rabbi Elazar  took his opening text for this lesson from here:
18.14: (Ecclesiastes 10:18) "Through laziness the beam-work (mikrah) will sink (yimakh), and through a sinking of hands the house will drip."  Because of 'laziness', who are the ones of Israel who were not occupied with Torah; the enemy of the Holy One, Blessed Be He[ie. Israel itself, due to its sins], became lowly (makh).
18.15: Indeed, 'lowly' means poor, as is said (Leviticus 27:8):  "And if he is too lowly for your valuation."  Indeed, 'beam-work' means the Holy One, Blessed Be He, as is said (Psalms 104:3):  "He [lays] the beam-work of His upper chamber in the waters."
18.16: Rav Nahman  took his opening text for this lesson from here:
18.17: (Psalms 124:1) "A song of ascents ... if Hashem had not been with us, let Israel say it now.  If Hashem had not been with us when a man arose against us..." (Psalms 124:2)  A 'man' and not a king.
18.18: Rava  took his opening text for this lesson from here:
18.19: (Proverbs 29:2) "With an increase of the righteous the people rejoice, and with the rule of the wicked the people sigh."  'With an increase of the righteous the people rejoice', these are Mordechai and Esther, as is written:  "And the city of Shushan was bright and joyful".  'And with the rule of the wicked the people sigh', this is Haman, as is written:  "And the city of Shushan was perplexed."
18.21: (Deuteronomy 4:7)  "For which great nation has God so near to it."
18.24: "And it came to pass (vayahi) in the days of Ahashverosh."
18.27: With this it is written (Deuteronomy 28:68):  "And there you will sell yourselves to your enemies as slaves and handmaidens, etc."
18.29: (Leviticus 26:44) "[I] did not cast them away nor did [I] abhor to them to annihilate them."  'I did not cast them away' in the days of the Greeks.  'Nor did I abhor them' in the days of Nebuchadnezzar.  'To annihilate them' in the days of Haman.  "To break my covenant with them" in the days of the Persians, "for I am Hashem their God", in the days of Gog and Magog.
18.30: In a Baraita it was taught:
18.31: 'I did not cast them away' in the days of the Chaldeans, when I caused Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah to stand up for them.  'Nor did I abhor them' in the days of the Greeks, when I caused Shimon the Righteous, the Hasmonean and his sons, and Mattathias the High Priest to stand up for them.  'To annihilate them in the days of Haman', when I caused Mordechai and Esther to stand up for them.  'To break my covenant with them' in the days of the Persians, when I caused the House of Rabbi and the Sages of the generations to stand up for them.  'For I am Hashem their God' for the future time to come, when there will not be any nation or linguistic group who will be able to have power over them.
18.33: (Numbers 33:55) "And if you do not disinherit the inhabitants of the land..."
18.35: (Numbers 33:56) "And it shall be that what I had thought to do to them I will do to you."
18.37: brother of the head, and of the same character as the head.
18.38: 'Brother of the head', brother of Nebuchadnezzar the wicked one who was called 'head' as is said (Daniel 2:38):  "You are the head of gold."
18.39: 'Of the same character as the head':  he killed, he sought to kill, he destroyed, he sought to destroy, as is said (Ezra 4:6):  "And in the reign of Ahashverosh, in the beginning of his reign, they wrote an accusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem.
18.41: The face of Israel was blackened in his days like the bottom of a pot.
18.46: Everyone was made poor in his days, as was said (Esther 10:1):  "And Ahashverosh the King placed a levy."
18.47: "That is Ahashverosh", he is wicked from beginning to end.
18.48: (Genesis 36:43) "That is Esau", he is wicked from beginning to end.  (Numbers 26:9) "Those are Dathan and Abiram", they are wicked from beginning to end.  (II Chronicles 28:22) "That is King Ahaz", he is wicked from beginning to end.
18.49: (I Chronicles 1:27) "Abram, that is Abraham", he is righteous from beginning to end.  (Exodus 6:26) "Those are Aaron and Moses", they are righteous from beginning to end.
18.50: (I Samuel 17:14) "And David, he is the smallest."  He maintained his 'smallness' (humility) from beginning to end.  Just as, in his youth, he humbled himself before one who was greater than he in Torah [knowledge], so during his reign he humbled himself before one who was greater than he in wisdom.
18.52: [this means] that he (Ahashverosh) became king through his own effort.
18.53: Some say this to praise him, and some say this to shame him.
18.54: 'Some say this to praise him', because there was no other person who was as prepared for the throne as he was.  'Some say this to shame him', because he was not fit for the throne, but he had an abundance of wealth so he gave and he ascended.
18.55: "From Hodu to Cush."  [Of] Rav and Shmuel, one said:
18.56: Hodu is at [one] end of the world, and Cush is at [the other] end of the world; and the one said:
18.57: Hodu and Cush are next to each other.  Just as he reigned over Hodu and Cush, so he reigned from [one] end of the earth to [the other] end.
18.58: Just like with this case, you say (I Kings 5:4):    "For he governs everything on this side of the river from the entrance Tiphsah to Gaza."  [Of] Rav and Shmuel,
18.60: Tiphsah is at [one] end of the world and Gaza is at [the other] end of the world; and the one said:
18.61: Tiphsah and Gaza are next to each other.  Just as he reigned over Tiphsah and Gaza, so he reigned over the whole world, all of it.
18.62: "Seven and twenty and one hundred provinces."  Rav Hisda said:
18.63: At the start he reigned over seven, then later he reigned over twenty [more], then later he reigned over one hundred [more].
18.64: But now, (Exodus 6:20) "And the years of the life of Amram were seven and thirty and one hundred years."  How do you interpret this?
18.65: Here it is different because the verse is superfluous since it is written:  "From Hodu to Cush".  Why do I have "seven and twenty and one hundred provinces"?
18.66: Learn from this that it is for [special] interpretation.
18.68: Three [kings] reigned over the entire world, and they are
18.70: 'Ahab', as it is written (I Kings 18:10):  "As Hashem your God lives, if there is a nation or a kingdom to which my lord has not stretched out to seek you, etc."  If it was that he did not reign over them, how could he have forced them to swear?
18.71: 'Nebuchadnezzar', as it is written (Jeremiah 27:8):  "And it shall be that the nation and the kingdom that does not put its neck into the yoke of the king of Babylon..."

19.0: Mnemonic:  Sh-S-D-K.  Are there no more?  (The mnemonic stand for Shlomo, Sennacherib, Darius, and Cyrus.  --trans.)
19.3: This pleases the one who said [first] a king, then a commoner.  But for the one who said [first] a king, then a commoner, then a king -- what is there to say?
19.4: The affair was different with Solomon, in that he reigned over the upper realm and over the lower realm, as is said (I Chronicles 29:23):  "And Solomon sat upon the throne of Hashem."
19.5: Then there was Sennacherib, as it was written (Isaiah 36:20):  "Who of all of the gods of these lands is the one that rescued their land from my hand?"
19.6: But there is Jerusalem, which he did not conquer.
19.7: But there is Darius, as it is written (Daniel 6:26):  "Darius the King wrote to all the peoples, nations, and languages that dwell in all the land, 'May your peace grow greatly'."
19.8: But there are seven [provinces] over which he did not reign, as it is written (Daniel 6:2):  "It seemed fair to Darius and he appointed over the kingdom one hundred twenty Persian governors."
19.9: But there is Cyrus, as it is written (Ezra 1:2):  "Thus said Cyrus king of Persia, 'Hashem has given all kingdoms of the earth to me'."
19.11: (Esther 1:2) "In those days when the king sat..."  And it is written afterward:  "Three [years into] his reign..."
19.13: What is [the meaning of] 'when [the king] sat'?  That after [some time on the throne] his mind was rested.
19.15: Belshazar calculated, but was mistaken.  I calculated and am not mistaken.
19.17: As it is written (Jeremiah 29:10):  "When seventy years are fulfilled for Babylon, I shall visit you."  And it is written (Daniel 9:2):  "To fulfill seventy years for the destruction of Jerusalem."
19.18: He calculated forty-five [years] of Nebuchadnezzar, twenty-three of Evil Merodach, and two of his own [reign].  That is seventy.
19.19: He brought out the vessels of the Holy Temple and he used them.
19.20: How do we know that Nebuchadnezzar reigned for forty-five years?
19.22: They were exiled in the seventh [year], they were exiled in the eighth, they were exiled in the eighteenth, they were exiled in the nineteenth.
19.23: The exile in the seventh[year] during the conquest of Jehoiakim was the exile of Jechoniah, which occurred in the eighth [year] of Nebuchadnezzar.
19.24: The exile in the eighteenth [year] during the conquest of Jehoiakim was the exile of Zedekiah, which occurred in the nineteenth [year] of Nebuchadnezzar.  As Master said:
19.25: [During his] first year, [Nebuchadnezzar] conquered Nineveh; in the second year he conquered Jehoiakim.  And it is written (Jeremiah 52:31):  "And it came to pass in the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiakim, King of Judah, in the twelfth month on the twenty-fifth of the month, that Evil Merodach, King of Babylon, [in the year of his reign] lifted the head of Jehoiakim, King of Judah and brought him out from prison."  Eight and thirty-seven.  Thus forty-five for Nebuchadnezzar.
19.26: And twenty-three [years] of Evil Merodach is a tradition.  And two of his own [reign] make seventy.
19.28: Now they will certainly not be redeemed.  He brought out the vessels of the Holy Temple and he used them.
19.29: We have here that which Daniel said to him:
19.30: (Daniel 5:23) "You have exalted yourself against the Master of Heaven and they have put the vessels of His House before you."  And it is written (Daniel 5:30):  "On that night Belshazar, the King [of the Chaldeans] was killed."  And it is written (Daniel 6:1):  "And Darius the Mede received the kingship at the age of sixty-two years."
19.32: He made a mistake.  I will calculate and will not make a mistake.
19.33: Is it written 'for the kingdom of Babylon'?
19.35: What does 'for Babylon' mean?  'For the exile of Babylon'.
19.36: How many [years] must be cut?  Eight.
19.37: He calculated, and he put in their place
19.38: one of Belshazar, five of Darius and Cyrus, and two of his own.  That is seventy.
19.39: Now that he saw that seventy had been fulfilled and they were not redeemed, he said:
19.40: Now they will certainly not be redeemed.  He brought out the vessels of the Holy Temple and he used them.
19.41: Satan came and danced with them.  Then he killed Vashti.
19.43: He also made a mistake, for he ought to count from the destruction of Jerusalem.
19.44: In the end, how many must be cut?  (Eleven.)  How many did he reign?  Fourteen.  In the fourteenth he ought to have [re]built the Holy Temple.
19.45: Why is it written (Ezra 4:24):  "Thereupon the work of the House of God that is in Jerusalem ceased."?

20.1: There was still another year for Babylon, and Darius stood up and completed it.
20.3: Even Daniel made a mistake with his calculation, as it is written (Daniel 9:2):  "In the first year of his reign I, Daniel, considered by means of the Scriptures..."  Because he said 'I considered', by implication he made a mistake.
20.4: In any event, there is a mutual difficulty with the verses.
20.5: It is written (Jeremiah 29:10) "fulfilled for Babylon", and it is written (Daniel 9:2) "for the destruction of Jerusalem".
20.7: [the first verse] was for general charging,
20.8: and so it is written (Ezra 1:2) "Thus said Cyrus, King of Persia:  Hashem, God of the heavens, has given to me all of the kingdoms on the earth and He has charged me with building for Him a house in Jerusalem."
20.9: Rav Nahman bar Rav Hisda explained:
20.10: Why is it written (Isaiah 45:1) "Thus said Hashem to His anointed, to Cyrus, whose right hand I grasped."?  Because Cyrus had been [genuinely] anointed?
20.11: Rather, the Holy One, Blessed Be He, said to the Anointed One:
20.12: I cry out to you about Cyrus.  I said, 'he will build my house and gather in my exiles'.
20.13: But he said (Ezra 1:3):  "Whoever among you from all of His people may go up..."
20.14: [It is written] (Esther 1:3):  "The army of Persia and Media, the noblemen..."  And it is written "...of the kings of Media and Persia."
20.16: They made a bargain with each other, [saying]:
20.17: 'if we bring kings you bring governors, and if you bring kings we will bring governors.'
20.18: (Esther 1:4) "When he showed the riches of his glorious kingdom..."  Rabbi Yose bar Hanina said:
20.19: [this] teaches that he wore the garments of a priest (kohen).
20.20: It is written here "the riches of his glorious greatness" and it is written there (Exodus 28:2) "for glory and for splendor".
20.21: [It is written] (Esther 1:5) "And when these days had been fulfilled, etc."  [Of] Rav and Shmuel,
20.23: 'he was a prudent king', and the other said
20.25: The one who said 'was a prudent king' reasoned that he did well in first bringing near those who were far away, since he could pacify the people of his city whenever he wished.
20.26: And the one who said 'was a stupid king' reasoned that he should have brought near the people of his city first, because if they [distant people] were to rebel against him, these [people of his city] would support him.
20.27: His students asked Rabbi Shimon ben Yohai:
20.28: Why did the enemies of Israel of that generation deserve extermination?
20.32: Because they were eager for the banquet of [Ahashverosh], the wicked one.
20.33: [He said to them]:  If so, then those [Jews] of Shushan should have been killed.  But for those [Jews] in the entire world, they should not have been killed.
20.37: Because they prostrated themselves to an image.
20.39: Then should there be partiality in that case?
20.41: They did not do these with conviction.  So the Holy One, Blessed Be He, did not do these [punishments] to them with conviction.  And so it is written (Lamentations 3:33):  "For He does not afflict from His heart."
20.42: (Esther 1:5) "In the courtyard of the garden of the king's house."  [Of] Rav and Shmuel,
20.44: 'those approved for the courtyard [were brought] to the courtyard; those approved for the garden [were brought] to the garden; those approved for the house [were brought to the house'.  And the other said
20.45: '[Ahashverosh] sat them in the courtyard, but it could not contain them, then in the garden, but it could not contain them; then he brought them into the house and it contained them'.
20.46: It was taught in a Baraita:
20.47: He sat them in the courtyard and opened two gates for them, one into the garden, and one into the house.
20.48: (Esther 1:6) "Hur (white), karpas (fine linen), and blue."  What is 'hur'?
20.51: white wool laid out for them.
20.54: "Upon silver rods and marble pillars, couches of gold and silver."
20.55: It was taught:  Rabbi Yehuda says that
20.56: those approved for silver [sat] on silver and those approved for gold [sat] on gold.
20.58: If so, you are bringing jealousy to the banquet!  Rather,
20.59: they were of silver and their legs were of gold.
20.61: stones that were dug up by their owners, and thus it says (Zechariah 9:16):  "Stones of a crown [obtained] from many trials upon his land."
20.62: "And pearl (dar) and paving stones."  Rav said:
20.63: rows (darei) and rows.  And Shmuel said:
20.64: There is a good stone in the seaside cities, and its name is darah.  He set it in the middle of a banquet and it lit up among them like noontime (tzaharah).
20.65: As the house of Rabbi Shmuel taught:
20.66: [It means] that [Ahashverosh] called out a [tax] amnesty (deror) for all merchants (sehor).
20.67: (Esther 1:7) "And they poured drinks in goblets of gold, and the goblets were repeats."  Shouldn't it be 'diverse'?
20.69: A voice came forth from heaven and said to them:
20.70: Your predecessors were finished off (kalu) because of [holy] vessels (kelim), and you are repeating after them!
20.71: "And royal wine in abundance."  Rav said:
20.72: this teaches that every individual was given wine to drink that was greater in years than he.
20.73: (Esther 1:8) "And the drinking was according to law (there was no coercion)."
20.75: Rabbi Hanan said in the name of Rabbi Meir:
20.76: According to the law of the Torah.  As the law of the Torah [mandates] more eating than drinking, so at the banquet of the wicked one there was more eating than drinking.
20.77: 'There was no coercion'.  Rabbi Elazar said:
20.78: this teaches that every individual drank from the wine of his province.
20.79: To be done according to the pleasure of each and every man.  Rava said:
20.80: to be done according to the pleasure of Mordechai and Haman; Mordechai, as is written "a Jewish man"; Haman, [as is written] "a man, an adversary, and an enemy".
20.81: (Esther 1:9) "Vashti the Queen also made a feast for the women in the royal house."  Shouldn't it be 'women's house'?

20.85: 'he with large pumpkins and his wife

21.4: But when worshippers of the stars eat and drink, they begin with nothing but words of frivolity.
