21.6: the Median women', others would say 'praiseworthy are
21.9: The vessel that I use is neither Median nor Persian; rather, it is Chalean.  Do you wish to see her?
21.11: yes, but only if she is naked.
21.12: Because with a measure that a man measures, they measure for him.
21.13: This teaches that Vashti, the wicked one, would bring the daughters of Israel, strip them naked, and make them do work on Shabbat.
21.14: For it was written:  "After these things, when the anger of king Ahashverosh abated, he remembered Vashti and what she had done, and what had been decreed against her."
21.15: As she had done, thus was it decreed against her.
21.16: "And Queen Vashti refused."  You know, she was licentious, as Master said:
21.17: the two of them intended to commit transgressions.  What is the reason that she did not come?
21.19: This teaches that leprosy (tzara'at) broke out on her.
21.20: It was taught in a Baraita:
21.21: [Gabriel came and put a tail on her.]
21.22: "And the king became very angry."  Why did it burn so greatly inside him?
21.25: 'Son of the stable keeper of my father,
21.26: My father drank wine while receiving a thousand, yet did not get drunk.  But that man became insensible with his wine.'
21.27: Immediately, his anger burned inside him.
21.28: "And the king said to the wise men."  Who are the wise men?  Rabbis.  "...who know the times..."  Those who know how to intercalate years and to fix new moons.
21.34: 'slay her',  then tomorrow when the wine abates from him, he will ask for her from us.
21.36: 'let her go', she is slighting his royal personage.
21.38: From the day that the Holy Temple was destroyed and we were exiled from our land, counsel has been taken from us and we do not have the knowledge to judge capital cases.
21.39: Go to Ammon and Moab, who remain in their places as wine remains atop its sediment.
21.40: With sound reasoning they said to him:
21.41: as it is written (Jeremiah 48:11) "Moab has been at ease from its youth and is settled on its sediment.  It has not been emptied from vessel to vessel, and it has not gone into exile.  Because of this, its taste has remained with it, and its scent has not changed."
21.42: Immediately, [he did so] and the one near to him was Carshena, Shetar, Admata, Tarshish, [etc.]
21.44: The whole verse is about the matter of [sacrificial] offerings, as is said:
21.45: 'Carshena' -- the ministering angels said before the Holy One, Blessed Be He,
21.46: Master of the Universe, did all of them (gentile nations) offer before You one year old lambs (karim b'nei shanah) in the way that Israel offered before You?
21.47: 'Shetar' -- did all of them offer before You two turtle-doves (shtei torim)?
21.48: 'Admata' -- did all of them build before You an earthen (adamah) altar?
21.49: 'Tarshish' -- did all of them serve You in priestly garments, of which it is written (Exodus 28:20) "yellow jasper (tarshish), onyx, and jasper"?
21.50: 'Meres' -- did all of them stir (mirsu) the blood before You?
21.51: 'Marsena' -- did all of them stir (mirsu) the afternoon offerings before You?
21.52: 'Memukhan' -- did all of them prepare (hekhinu) a table before You?
21.55: And why was he called Memukhan?  Because he was destined (mukhan) for retribution.
21.57: from here [we see] that a common man leaps to the head [of the line].
21.58: "That every man rules in his house."  Rava said:
21.59: if not for the first letters, nothing would remain from the enemies of Israel, fugitive or survivor.
21.61: what is this that he sends to us 'that every man rules in his house?
21.63: Even a common weaver will be the officer in his house!
21.66: Why is it written (Proverbs 13:16) "Every prudent man acts with understanding, but a foolish man spreads folly"?  'Every prudent man acts with understanding', this is David as it is written (I Kings 1:2) "And his servants said to him, 'let them seek for my lord the king a young virgin'".  Everyone who had a daughter brought her to him.
21.67: 'But a foolish man spreads folly', this is Ahashverosh as it is written "And let the king appoint officials."
21.68: Everyone who had a daughter hid her from him.
21.69: "There was a man of Judah in the fortress of Shushan, etc., a man of [the tribe of] Benjamin."
21.71: If to consider the pedigree [of Mordechai], then it should go back to Benjamin!
21.74: All of them were forms of his name.
21.75: 'Ben Yair', a son who gave light (he'ir) for the eyes of Israel through his prayer.  'Ben Shimi', a son of whom He listened (shama) to his prayer.  'Ben Kish', who knocked (hikish) on the gates of mercy and they were opened for him.
21.76: It calls him a Judahite.  Thus he came from [the tribe of] Judah.  And it calls him a Benjaminite.  Thus he came from [the tribe of] Benjamin.
21.78: Mordechai was adorned with his names.
21.79: Rava bar bar Hanah said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi:
21.80: his father was from Benjamin and his mother was from Judah.
21.82: the families were jealous of each other.  The family of Judah would say,
21.83: 'I caused Mordechai to be born, because David did not slay Shimi ben Gera'.  And the family of Benjamin said,
21.86: the community of Israel said the opposite thing.
21.87: See what a Judahite did to me and what a Benjaminite paid me.  'What a Judahite did to me.'

22.0: Because David did not slay Shimi, Mordechai was born from me, and he mocked Haman.
22.1: 'And what a Benjaminite paid me.'  Because Saul did not slay Agog, from whom Haman descended, and he caused trouble for Israel.
22.3: In reality, he descended from Benjamin.  Then why is he called a 'Judahite'?  Because he renounced the worship of foreign [gods].
22.4: And anyone who renounces the worship of foreign [gods] is called a 'Judahite', as it is written (Daniel 3:12) "There are men of Judah, etc."
22.5: Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, as he opened Chronicles, said this:
22.6: All of your words are one, and we know how to examine them.
22.7: (I Chronicles 4:18) "And his wife the Judahite bore Yered the father of Gedor, and Hever the father of Socho, and Yekutiel the father of Zanoah; and these are the sons of Bityah the daughter of Pharaoh, whom Mered took."
22.8: Why was she called a Judahite?  Because she renounced the worship of foreign [gods], as it is written (Exodus 2:5) "And the daughter of Pharaoh went down to cleanse herself in the river."  And Rabbi Yohanan said
22.9: that she went down to cleanse herself from the idols of her father's house.
22.12: To say to you that anyone who raises an orphan boy or girl in his house, the verse treats him as though he bore him [or her].
22.13: 'Yered', this is Moses.  And why was he called Yered?  Because manna came down (yarad) for Israel in his days.
22.14: 'Gedor', because he fenced (gadar) the breaches of Israel.  'Hever', because he joined (hiber) Israel to their Father who was in the heavens.
22.15: 'Socho', because he acted for Israel like a shelter (sukkah).
22.16: 'Yekutiel', because Israel had faith in God (kivu el) in his days.
22.17: 'Zanoah', because he caused Israel to reject (hizniach) their sins.
22.18: 'Father of', 'father of', 'father of':  a father in Torah, a father in wisdom, a father in prophecy.
22.19: And these are the sons of Bityah whom Mered took.  But was his name Mered?
22.21: Said the Holy One, Blessed Be He:
22.22: Let Caleb, who rebelled (marad) against the counsel of the spies, come and take the daughter of Pharaoh, who rebelled against the idols of her father's house.
22.25: he went into exile under his own power.
22.26: And he raised Hadassah.  She is called Hadassah and she is called Esther.
22.27: It was taught:  Rabbi Meir says that
22.28: her name is Esther.  Then why was she called Hadassah?  Because of the reputation of the righteous, who are called myrtles (hadasim).  And thus it says (Zechariah 1:8) "And he was standing among the myrtles".
22.29: Rabbi Yehudah says that Hadassah was her name.  Then why was she called Esther?  Because she would hide (setarah) her affairs.  As was said, "Esther did not tell anything about her people, etc."
22.31: her name was Hadassah.  Then why was she called Esther?  Because the nations of the world would call her Istahar (Venus).
22.33: Esther was neither tall nor short, but medium -- like a myrtle.
22.34: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korach said that
22.35: Esther was greenish, and a chord of lovingkindness (hesed) ran through her.
22.36: 'Because she did not have a father or mother'.  Why [also] 'and when her father and mother died'?
22.38: when she conceived her, her father died; when she gave birth, her mother died.
22.39: "And when her father and mother died, Mordechai took her as his own daughter."  It was taught in the name of Rabbi Meir:
22.40: Do not read 'for a daughter'.  Rather, [read] 'for a [member of his] household' (i.e., wife).  And thus it says (II Samuel 12:3) "And the poor man had nothing but one small ewe-lamb which he had bought and nurtured; she grew up together with him and his children, she ate from his bread and she drank from his cup, she lay down in his bosom and was like a daughter to him."  Because she would lie in his bosom, was she (like a daughter) to him?
22.41: Rather (like a house/wife).  Also here, 'like a house/wife'.
22.43: that she would count the days of the week by them.
22.44: "And he changed her and her maidens, etc."  Rav said
22.45: that he fed her Jewish food.
22.49: legumes.  And thus it says (Daniel 1:16) "And the waiter carried away the food and gave them legumes."
22.50: "Six months with oil of myrrh."  What is 'oil of myrrh'?
22.52: cinnamon.  Rav Huna said oil from olives that have not grown a third.
22.53: It was taught:  Rabbi Yehuda says
22.54: oil of unripe olives, oil from olives that have not grown a third.  And why do they smear it?  Because it removes the hair and makes the flesh pliant.
22.55: "In the evening she came and in the morning she returned."  Rabbi Yohanan said
22.56: from the disgrace of the wicked one we learn something praiseworthy about him, that he did not 'use his bed' during the day.
22.57: "And Esther found favor."  Rabbi Elazar said that
22.58: this teaches that each and every person imagined her to be like one of his nation.
22.59: "Esther was taken to King Ahashverosh, to his palace in the tenth month, which is the month of Tevet", a month which favors body [close] to body.
22.60: "And the king loved Esther more than all the women, and she found more favor and kindness before him than all the [other] virgins."
22.62: [if] he sought to experience a virgin, he experienced it; [if] to experience a non-virgin, he experienced it.
22.63: "And the king made a great banquet".  He made the banquet, but she did not reveal [her origins] to him.  He suspended the head tax, but she did not reveal to him.  He sent gifts, but she did not reveal to him.
22.64: "And when the virgins were gathered together a second time, etc."  He went and he pondered counsel from Mordechai.
22.66: a woman does not become jealous, except when 'at the thigh' of her fellow woman.  And even so, she did not reveal to him, as it is written "Esther did not tell about her birthplace, etc."

23.0: (Job 36:7) "He does not take his eyes away from the righteous"?  As a reward for Rachel's discretion, she was privileged to have Saul descend from her.  And as a reward for Saul's discretion, he was privileged to have Esther descend from him.
23.1: What was Rachel's discretion?  As it is written (Genesis 29:12) "Jacob told Rachel that he was the brother of her father."
23.2: Now, was he the brother of her father?
23.3: Was he not the son of her father's sister?
23.8: but my father is a deceiver, and you will not be able to outwit him."
23.10: "I am his brother as a deceiver."
23.12: "is it permitted to the righteous to walk in the way of deceit?"
23.14: "yes, [as it is written] (II Samuel 22:27) 'With the pure you act purely, and with the perverted you deal torturously.'"
23.18: "I have a sister who is older than me, and he will not marry me before her."
23.20: When the [wedding] night arrived she said,
23.21: "now my sister will be put to shame.  She gave [the signs] to her."
23.22: And so it is written (Genesis 29:25) "And it came to pass in the morning that, behold, it was Leah."  Does this imply that it was not Leah until now?
23.24: because of signs that Rachel gave to Leah, he did not know until now.
23.25: Therefore, she was privileged to have Saul descend from her.
23.26: And what was Saul's discretion?  As it is written (I Samuel 10:16) "But he did not tell him the matter of the kingdom as Samuel had said."  He was privileged that Esther descended from him.
23.28: When the Holy One, Blessed Be He, apportions greatness to a person, he apportions [it] to his children and his children's children until the end of all generations as it says (Job 36:7) "He will seat them to endure and be exalted, (etc.)"  But if he becomes arrogant, the Holy One, Blessed Be He, humbles him as it says (Job 36:8) "And if they are bound with chains, etc."
23.29: "And Esther did as Mordechai said."  Rabbi Yirmiyah said
23.30: that she would show her menstrual blood to the Sages.
23.31: [This is] as it was when he brought her up.  Rabbah bar Lima said (in the name of Rav)
23.32: that she would stand up from the breast of Ahashverosh, then she would immerse and sit at the breast of Mordechai.
23.33: "In those days, while Mordechai was sitting at the king's gate, Bigtan and Teresh became angry."  Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yohanan:
23.34: The Holy One, Blessed Be He, caused a lord to be angry with his servants to do the will of a righteous one.  And who is it?  Joseph, as it is said (Genesis 41:12) "And there was a Hebrew lad with us, etc."
23.35: [And] servants with their lord to do a miracle for a righteous one.  And who is it?  Mordechai, as it is written "And the matter was known to Mordechai, etc."
23.37: Bigtan and Teresh were two Tarsians, and they conversed in the Tarsian language.  They were saying,
23.38: "From the day that this [woman] came we have not slept.  Come, let us put poison into the bowl in order that he will die."
23.39: But they did not know that Mordechai was one who sat in the Chamber of Hewn Stone or that he knew seventy languages.
23.41: "But my post and your post are not equal."
23.43: "I will watch my post and your post."
23.44: And so it is written "And the matter was investigated and was found..."  Because they were not found at their posts.
23.47: After the Holy One, Blessed Be He, created a cure for the wound.
23.49: the Holy One, Blessed Be He, does not wound Israel until he has created a cure for them beforehand, as it is said (Hosea 7:1) "As I have cured Israel, so the sin of Ephraim will be revealed."  But [for] the nations of the world, it is not so.  [God] wounds them and afterwards He creates a cure, as it is written (Isaiah 19:22) "And Hashem will strike Egypt, striking and curing."
23.50: "And it was contemptible in his eyes to send out his hand against Mordechai alone."  Rava said:  At first, [he wanted] only Mordechai.  In the end, [he wanted] the people of Mordechai.  And who is it?  The Rabbis and, in the end, all the Jews.
23.51: He cast a 'pur' (lot), that is the lot.  It was taught:
23.52: When the lot fell on the month of Adar he rejoiced greatly.  He said
23.53: the lot fell for me on the month in which Moses died.
23.54: But he did not know that [Moses] died on the seventh of Adar, and [Moses] was born on the seventh of Adar.
23.56: There is no one who knows the language of wickedness like Haman.
23.60: "I am afraid of their God, that He does not serve me as he served my predecessors."
23.62: "They have been lazy regarding the commandments."
23.67: Perhaps you will say that I am making a gap in your kingdom, [but] they are scattered among the nations.  Perhaps you will say that there is some benefit from them, they are separated like a single slice that does not produce fruit.
23.68: Then perhaps you will say that they make up a province, [but] a saying teaches 'in all the provinces of your kingdom'.
23.69: Their laws are different than any other people's;  they do not eat from our [food], they do not marry our [women], and they do not marry their [women] to us.
23.70: And they do not perform the laws of the king, for they procrastinate the entire year [saying], 'today is Shabbat', 'today is Passover'.
23.71: And there is no benefit to the king to let them remain, for they eat and drink and despise the kingdom.
23.72: And even if a fly falls into the cup of one of them, he casts it out and drinks,
23.73: but if my lord the king touches the cup of one of them, he flings it to the ground and does not drink.
23.74: "If it pleases the king, let it be written to destroy them, and ten thousand talents of silver, etc."  Resh Lakish said:
23.75: It was publicly known before The One who spoke and the world came into being that, in the future, Haman would weigh out shekels over Israel; so he caused them to precede their shekels by [Haman's] shekels.
23.77: on the first of Adar they announce [a reminder of] the shekel [tax] and the mixture [of seeds].
23.78: Then the king said to Haman, "the silver is given to you -- and the people -- to do with it as is good in your eyes."  Rabbi Abba said:

24.0: A parable about Ahashverosh and Haman:  to what thing is it analogous?
24.1: To two people...  One has a mound in the midst of his field.  One has a trench in his field.
24.2: The owner of the ditch said,
24.3: 'if only he would give to me this mound with compensation'.
24.4: The owner of the mound said,
24.5: 'if only he would give to me this ditch with compensation'.
24.6: After some days, they encountered each other.  The owner of the ditch said to the owner of the mound,
24.9: 'oh that you will take it gratuitously!'.
24.10: "The king removed his seal-ring."  Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said:
24.11: the removal of the seal-ring is greater than [all] forty-eight prophets and seven prophetesses who prophesied for Israel, because all of them could not turn them back to good [ways], while the removal of the seal-ring did turn them back to good [ways].
24.13: Forty-eight prophets and seven prophetesses were prophesing for Israel, and they did not subtract from or add to what was written in the Torah, except the reading of the Megillah.
24.15: Rabbi Hiyya bar Avin said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korach:
24.16: if [when going] from slavery to freedom they sang a song, then [going] from death to life should they not do thusly?
24.17: If so, should we also say Hallel?
24.18: [No,] because Hallel is not said over a miracle that occurred outside the Land.
24.19: The going out of Egypt -- that was a miracle that occurred outside the Land.  How then do we sing a song?
24.21: while Israel had not entered the Land, it was proper to sing a song [for a miracle] in every land;
24.22: after Israel had entered the Land, it was not proper to sing a song in every land.
24.24: Reading [the Megillah] is [equivalent to] Hallel.  Rava said:
24.25: there it is reasonable.  (Psalms 113:1) "Praise, O servants of Hashem..."  And not servants of Pharaoh.  But here, 'praise, O servants of Hashem'?  And not servants of Ahashverosh?
24.26: We are still servants of Ahashverosh.
24.27: There is a difficulty between Rava and Rav Nahman.
24.28: And here it was taught:  after they entered the Land, it was not proper to sing a song in every land.  Since they were exiled, they turned back to regarding it as proper as it was at first.
24.29: And further, were there no other [prophets]?
24.30: But isn't it written (I Samuel 1:1) "And it came to pass there was one man from Ramatayim-Tzophim..."?  One of two hundred seers who prophesied for Israel?
24.31: In any event, there were many.
24.33: Many were the prophets who rose up for Israel, double those who left Egypt.  However, the prophesy that was needed for [future] generations was written down.  And so, if it was not needed, it was not written down.
24.35: a man who comes from two heights that watch each other.
24.37: a man who comes from men who were standing at the high point of the world.
24.38: And who are they?  The sons of Korach,
24.39: as it is written (Numbers 26:11) "And the sons of Korach did not die."
24.40: It was taught in the name of our Rabbi:
24.41: a place was set apart for them in Gehinnom, and they stood upon it.
24.43: Sarah, Miriam, Deborah, Hannah, Abigail, Huldah, and Esther.
24.44: Sarah, as it is written (Genesis 11:29) "The father of Milcah and the father of Yiskah".  And Rabbi Yitzhak said:
24.46: And why was she called Yiskah?  Because she saw (sakah) with a holy spirit, as is said (Genesis 21:12) "Anything that Sarah says to you, heed her voice..."
24.48: Yiskah, because everyone saw (sukin) her beauty.
24.49: Miriam, as it is written (Exodus 15:20) "And Miriam the prophetess, sister of Aaron, took..."  And not the sister of Moses?
24.50: Rav Nahman said in the name of Rav:
24.51: Because she prophesied as the sister of Aaron saying,
24.52: "in the future my mother will give birth to a son who will save Israel".
24.53: And in the hour in which [Moses] was born, the entire house was filled with light.  Her father stood up and kissed her on her head.  He said to her,
24.54: "my daughter, your prophecy has been fulfilled".
24.55: And when they threw him into the river, her father stood up and slapped her upon her head and he said to her,
24.57: Thus it is written (Exodus 2:4) "His sister stationed herself at a distance to know..."  To know what would happen with the end of her prophecy.
24.58: Deborah, as it is written (Judges 4:4) "And Deborah, a prophetess, a woman of Lapidot."
24.59: What does 'a woman of Lapidot' mean? Because she was making wicks for the Holy Place.
24.60: (Judges 4:5) "And she was sitting under a date-palm."  Why did she study under a date-palm?"
24.64: In the case of the date-palm, it has but one heart.  Then the Israel that came in that generation had but one heart for their Father in heaven.
24.65: Hannah, as it is written (I Samuel 2:1) "And Hannah prayed and she said, 'my heart rejoices in Hashem, my horn is exalted in Hashem.'"  'My horn is exalted' and not 'my pan is exalted'.
24.66: David and Solomon, who had been anointed with a 'horn', and their kingdom was extended.  Saul and Yehu, who had been anointed with a 'pan', their kingdom was not extended.
24.67: (I Samuel 2:2) "There is none as holy as Hashem, for there is none besides You..."  Rav Yehudah bar Menashya said:
24.68: Do not read 'besides You' (biltekha), rather 'outlives You' (lebalotekha).
24.69: Because the measure of the Holy One, Blessed Be He, is not like the measure of flesh and blood.

29.23: (Genesis 47:31) "And Israel bowed at the head of the bed."  Rabbi Benjamin bar Yefet said in the name of Rabbi Elazar,
29.24: a fox in its time -- bow down to it.
29.25: (Genesis 50:21) "And he comforted them and he spoke to their heart."  Rabbi Benjamin bar Yefet said in the name of Rabbi Elazar,
29.26: this teaches that he said to them words that are received by the heart.
29.27: If ten lamps are not able to extinguish one lamp, how is one lamp able to extinguish ten lamps?
29.28: (Esther 8:16) "And to the Jews there was light and happiness and joy and honor."  Rav Yehudah said,
29.29: 'Light' is Torah, and thus it says (Proverbs 6:23) "For a commandment is a lamp and Torah is light."
29.30: 'Happiness' is a Festival (Yom Tov) and thus it says (Deuteronomy 16:14) "And be happy on your Festival."  'Joy' is circumcision, and thus it says (Psalms 119:162) "I rejoice at your word."
29.31: And 'honor' is tefillin, and thus it says (Deuteronomy 28:10) "And all the peoples of the earth will see that the name Hashem is upon you, and they will be in awe of you."  And it was taught:  Eliezer the Great says,
29.32: this is the tefillin for the head.
29.33: "And Parshandata, etc. the ten sons of Haman..."  Rav Adda, who was from Yafo, said that
29.34: the ten sons of Haman and [the word] 'ten' need to be pronounced in one breath.
29.35: What is the reason?  The soul of each and every one of them left at the same time.
29.37: the letter vav in Vaizata needs to be extended as a pole like a rudder on the Librut [river].
29.39: Each and every one of them were hanged on the same pole.
29.41: Rabbi Shila, a man of the village of Temarta, expounded:
29.42: all songs -- all of them -- are written a small brick (writing) above a brick (blank space), and a brick above a small brick, outside of this song and [the song of] the kings of Canaan, which are a small brick above a small brick and a brick above a brick.
29.44: So that they will not rise up from their downfall.
29.45: "And the King said to Esther the Queen, 'In Shushan the capital, the Jews have killed..."  Rabbi Abahu said,
29.46: this teaches that an angel came and slapped him in his mouth.
29.47: "And when she came before the king, he said with the scroll..."  'He said'?
29.51: that he should say orally what is written on the scroll.
29.52: "...words of peace and truth."  Rabbi Tanhum said, though some say Rabbi Assi said,
29.53: this teaches that [the Megillah scroll] needs ruled lines like a real Torah.
29.54: And Esther's order stood.  'Esther's order' alone?  The words concerning the fasts did not?
29.56: the words concerning the fast and Esther's order [both] stood concerning these Purim [regulations].
29.57: 'For Mordechai the Jew was viceroy to King Achashverosh, and great to the Jews, and favorable to the majority of his brethren'- To the majority of his brethren, but not to all of his brethren. This teaches,
29.58: That a portion of the Sanhedrin [head Jewish court, made of 120 Sages] split off from him."
29.60: "Greater is the Study of Torah than the saving of lives,
29.61: For originally, Mordechai was considered after four; and after [he busied himself in saving lives, he was considered] after five.
29.62: Originally, it is written: "Who came with Zerubavel: Yeshua, Nechemiah, Sheriah, Ra'aliah, Mordechai Bilshan (Ezra 2:2)," and afterwards, it is written: "Those who came with Zerubavel: Yeshua, Nechemiah, Azariah, Ra'amiah, Nachmani, Mordechai Bilshan (Nehemiah 6:10)."
29.63: Rav, or some say Rabbi Shmuel the son of Marta, said,
29.64: "Greater is the Study of Torah than the building of the Temple, for all the time that Baruch the son of Neriah was alive, Ezra did not leave him and go up [to Jerusalem]."
29.65: Rabba said, "Rabbi Yitzchak the son of Shmuel the son of Marta said:
29.66: "Greater is the Study of Torah than honoring one's parents, for all of the years that Jacob was in the Academy of Eber, he was not punished [for leaving his parents]."

30.0: "Why were the years of Ishmael counted? To calculate with them the years of Jacob.
30.1: As it is written, 'And these are the years of the life of Yishmael: 137 years (Genesis 25:17).'"
30.2: How much older was Ishmael than Isaac? Fourteen years, as it is written: "And Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar gave bore Ishmael to Abram (Genesis 16:16)." And it is written: "And Abraham was 100 years old when Isaac, his son, was born to him (Genesis 21:5)."
30.3: And it is written: "And Isaac was sixty when they were born (Genesis 25:26)."
30.4: How old was Ishmael when Jacob was born? [He] was seventy-four [years old.] How many years were left in his life? Sixty-three.
30.6: "Jacob, our father, was sixty-three when he was blessed by his father, and at that same time Ishmael died, as it is written: 'And Esau saw that he had blessed, etc. And Esau went to Ishmael and he took [in marriage] Machalat, the daughter of Ishmael, the sister of Nevi'oth (Genesis 28:6).'" Because it is said, 'the daughter of Ishmael,' don't I know that she is the sister of Nevi'oth?
30.7: This teaches us that Ishmael consecrated her [to Esau], but he died and Nevi'oth married her off [to Esau].
30.8: Sixty-three and fourteen [in Aram] until Joseph was born makes seventy-seven [the age of Jacob when Joseph was born].
30.9: And it is written: "And Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh (Genesis 41:46)," which makes 107 [years of Jacob's life]. Seven [years] of plenty and two [years] of famine make 116 years. And it is written: "And Pharaoh said to Jacob, 'How many years have you lived?'
30.10: And Jacob said to Pharaoh, 'The years of my living are 130'(Genesis 47:8)," but aren't they [only one-hundred and] sixteen?
30.12: The fourteen years that he was in the Academy of Eber are not counted for him [between the sixty-three and the fourteen in Aram].
30.14: "Jacob was in the Academy of Eber, hidden away, for fourteen years.
30.15: Eber died two years after Jacob went down to Aram Naharayim.
30.16: [Jacob] went out from [the Academy of Eber] and came to Aram Naharayim.
30.17: It is found that when he stood by the well, he was seventy-seven."
30.18: And how do we know that he wasn't punished? As it is taught,
30.19: "It is found that Joseph, who left his father for twenty-two years, is like Jacob our father, just like how he left his father."
30.20: The [years of being away] of Jacob were thirty-six [not twenty-two]!
30.22: The fourteen [years] that he was in the Academy of Eber are not counted for him.
30.23: All in all, he was in the house of Laban for twenty years,
30.24: but he was on the road four two years,
30.26: "He went out from Aram Naharayim and came to Sukkot, and he made [booths] there for eighteen months, as it says, 'And Jacob traveled to Sukkot, and he built for himself a house, and for his cattle he made booths (Genesis 33:17).'
30.27: And in Beit El, he built for six months and offered sacrifices."
30.28: We shall return to you, [Chapter] "The Megillah is read."
30.29: Mishnah: He who reads the Megillah in an irregular manner, does not fulfill his obligation;
30.30: If he read it by heart, or read a translation in any language [other than Hebrew] he did not fulfill his obligation.
30.31: But we do read it in a foreign language to those who [only] understand a foreign language; and someone who only knows a foreign language who heard [the Megillah] in Hebrew has fulfilled his obligation.
30.32: If he read it with breaks, and slumbered [in the middle], he has fulfilled his obligation.
30.33: If he was writing it, expounding it, or correcting it [and thus read the Megillah]: If he intended [to make this his Megillah reading], he has fulfilled his obligation; and if not, then he has not fulfilled his obligation.
30.34: If [the Megillah] was written in paint, in red dye, in gum, or in vitriol black, on paper or on rough vellum, he has not fulfilled his obligation. [The obligation is not fulfilled] until it is written in Hebrew on parchment, in black ink.
30.35: Gemara: From where do we learn these words [that the Megillah must be written in order]?
30.37: "For the text said , "Like their writings and like their times." Just like their times are not [celebrated] out of order,
30.38: So too their writings are not [read] out of order." But concerning reading it is not written here,
30.39: [Rather,] the celebration is written (meaning, the words, "Like their writings," refer to celebration), as it is written [in that verse], "To celebrate the two days."
30.40: Rather, [we learn that it is prohibited to read the Megillah out of order] from here:
30.41: As it is written, "And these days are remembered and celebrated." It compares remembrance to celebration. Just like the celebration cannot be done out of order, so too the remembrance cannot be done out of order.
30.43: "And so too (meaning, the following things cannot be read out of order), regarding Hallel, and so too, regarding Shema and the [Amida] prayer."
30.44: [Regarding] Hallel, from where [do we learn this]?
30.46: "As it is written [in Hallel], 'From the rising of the sun to its setting (Psalms 113:3) [meaning, just as the day goes in order, from sunrise to sunset, so too Hallel goes in order].'"
30.48: "This is the day that G-d made (Psalms 118: 24) [meaning, just as the day goes in order, so too Hallel goes in order]." Rabbi Oyah said,
30.49: "Let the name of G-d be blessed (Psalms 113:2) [the word let implies, let it be as it is]." And Rabbi Nachman the son of Yitzchak, or some say Rabbi Acha the son of Ya'akov, say from here:
30.50: "From now until forever (Psalms 113:2) [ meaning, just as time goes in order, so too Hallel goes in order]."
30.51: The reading of Shema [must be in order], as it is taught:
30.52: "The reading of Shema [must be] like it is written; the words of Rebbi [Yehudah the Prince]. And the Sages say,
30.54: What is the reasoning of Rebbi [Yehudah the Prince]?

31.0: "And they shall be (Deuteronomy 6:6)-" [Meaning,] in the way they are, they shall be.
31.1: And as for the Rabbis, what is their reasoning?
31.2: For the text says, "Listen (Deuteronomy 6:4)-" [Meaning,] listen in whatever language you listen in.
31.3: But [regarding] Rebbi [Yehudah the Prince], isn't it also written "Listen"?
31.5: "Make your ears hear what is coming from your mouth."
31.6: Whereas the Rabbis held as those who said,
31.7: "He who reads Shema and does not make his ears hear has fulfilled his obligation."
31.8: But [regarding] the Rabbis, isn't it also written, "And they shall be"?
31.9: [Rather,] it obligates you, to not read Shema out of order.
31.10: And [regarding] Rebbi [Yehudah the Prince's opinion], from where do you know that you cannot read Shema out of order?
31.11: From the words, "These words (Deuteronomy 6:6) [which implies the words in their present state]."
31.12: But [regarding] the Rabbis, the words, "These words," have no [halakhic] meaning.
31.13: If we were to say that Rebbi [Yehudah the Prince] thought, "All of the Torah was given in all languages, for if you thought that it was given in Hebrew, why would I write, 'And they shall be' [as it would be unnecessary]?
31.14: It is needed for if you would have thought that Shema was according to the Rabbis, G-d wrote 'And they shall be' [which disproves that thought].
31.15: If we were to say that the Rabbis thought, "All of the Torah was given in Hebrew, for if you thought that it was given in all languages, why would I write, 'Listen' [as it would be unnecessary]?
31.16: It is needed for if you thought thought that 'And they shall be' follows Rebbi [Yehudah the Prince], G-d wrote 'Listen' [which disproves that thought].
31.17: [Regarding the Amidah] prayer, from where do we know [that we cannot read it out of order]?
31.19: "Shimon HaPakuli organized the eighteen blessing before Rabban Gamliel, in order in Yavneh."
31.20: Rabbi Yochanan said, or some say it was taught in a Mishnah,
31.21: "120 elders, and among them some prophets, instituted eighteen blessings in order.
31.23: "From where [do we learn] that we mention the forefathers [in the Amidah]? As it is said, "Ascribe unto the Lord, O sons of the strong (Psalms 29:1) [meaning, the patriarchs]." And from where [do we learn] to mention [the] powers [of G-d]? As it is said, "Ascribe unto the Lord honor and strength (Psalms 29:1)." And from where [do we learn] to mention the holiness [of G-d]? As it is said, "Ascribe unto the Lord the gory of his name; bow to the Lord in the beauty of holiness (Psalms 29:2)."
31.24: And why did they see fit to mention wisdom after holiness? As it is said, "And they shall sanctify the Holy One of Jacob, and the G-d of Israel they shall praise (Isaiah 29:23)." And it is put next to it, "And the faltering of spirit shall know wisdom (Isaiah 29:24)."
31.25: And why did they see fit to mention forgiveness after wisdom? As it is written "And in his heart he shall understand, and he shall return and be healed (Isaiah 6:10)."
31.26: Or maybe, let us say [to mention] healing [directly] after forgiveness?
31.27: [It is] not as you might have thought, as it is written "And he will return to Hashem, for he shall mercy him; and to our G-d, for he is abundant to forgive (Isaiah 55:7)."
31.28: And what was seen to make this verse more important than that verse?
31.30: "Who forgives all your sins, who heals all your illnesses, who saves the anointed of your life (Psalms 103:3)."
31.31: [Meaning,] to mention salvation and healing after forgiveness.
31.32: But isn't it written [above], "And he shall return and be healed"?
31.33: This is not the healing of illnesses, rather it is the healing of forgiveness.
31.34: And why did they see fit to mention redemption seventh?
31.36: "Because we are, in the future, to be redeemed on the Sabbatical [year]; therefore they set it in seventh."
31.38: "In the sixth year, voices, in the Sabbatical [year], battles, and after the Sabbatical [year] the descendant of David comes [and so the redemption is after the Sabbatical year]?"
31.39: The battles are also the beginning of redemption.
31.40: And why did they see fit to mention healing eighth?
31.42: "Because the Brit Milah is given on the eighth [day of the child's life.]"
31.43: And why did they see fit to mention the blessing of the years ninth? Rabbi Alexandri said,
31.44: "[To model it] against the raisers of prices, as it is written,
31.45: 'Break the arm of the wicked (Psalms 10:15) [referring to the raisers of prices],' and when David said it, he said it in the [pseudo-]ninth [psalm]."
31.46: And why did they see fit to mention the gathering of the exiles after the blessing of the years? As it is written, "And you, O mountains of Israel, give your leaves and carry your fruit for my nation Israel, for they are soon to come (Ezekiel 36:8)."
31.47: And as soon as the exiles are gathered, judgement is done to the wicked, as it is said:
31.48: "And I shall turn my hand on you, and purge your dross with lye (Isaiah 1:25)," and it is written [in the following verse], "And I shall return your judges as it was earlier (Isaiah 1:26)."
31.49: And as soon as justice is done to the wicked, the rebellious sinners are destroyed, and the haughty evildoers are included with them, as it is said,
31.50: "And the rebellious sinners shall be broken; and the transgressors shall be together consumed (Isaiah 1:28)."
31.51: And as soon as the rebellious are destroyed, the horn of the righteous is raised, as it is written, "And all the horns of the wicked I shall raze; let the horns of the righteous be raised (Psalms 75:11)." And the righteous gentiles (or, converts) are included with the righteous, as it is said, "From age you shall stand; and you shall honor the face of an elder (Leviticus 19:32)." And it is put next to it, "And if a stranger shall live among you (Leviticus 19:33)."
31.52: And where are their horns raised? In Jerusalem, as it is said, "Ask for the peace of Jerusalem; may your lovers have tranquility (Psalms 122:6)."
31.53: And as soon as Jerusalem (i.e. the Temple) is rebuilt, [the Messiah, who is the descendant of] David comes, as it is said,

32.0: "Afterwards, the Children of Israel shall return, and they shall seek Hashem, their G-d, and [the continuation of the dynasty of] David, their king.
32.1: And as soon as David comes, prayer comes, as it is said, "And I shall bring them to my holy mountain, and I shall make them happy in my house of prayer (Isaiah 56:7)."
32.2: And as soon as prayer comes, [Temple] service comes, as it is said [in the above verse], "Their elevation offerings and sacrifices [shall be] pleasing on my altar."
32.3: And as soon as [Temple] service comes, thanksgiving comes, as it is said, "He who sacrifices a thanksgiving offering shall honor me (Psalms 50:23)."
32.4: And why did they see fit to mention the Priestly Blessing after thanksgiving? As it is written, "And Aaron raised his hands towards the nation, and he blessed them, and he went down from doing the sin-, elevation-, and peace offerings (Leviticus 9:22)."
32.5: I would [therefore] say [that it should be mentioned] prior to [Temple] service [seeing as Aaron blessed the people and then the offerings came]?
32.6: You should not think that, as it is written, "And he went down from doing the sin offering, etc."
32.7: Is it written, 'to do'? It is written 'from doing' [meaning, Aaron didn't go down to do the offerings, he went down from already doing them in the past].
32.8: [Therefore, shouldn't it] be said after [Temple] service?
32.9: You should not think that, as it is written, "He who sacrifices a thanksgiving offering (Psalms 50:23) [meaning, thanksgiving comes right after sacrifice]."
32.10: What was seen to consider this verse more than that verse?
32.11: It is explained, that worship and thanksgiving are one [Hebrew] word [in the verse; the word 'Todah' means both a sacrifice and thanks].
32.12: And why did they see fit to say, "Bring peace," after the Priestly Blessing? As it is written, "And put my name upon Israel; and I shall bless them (Numbers 6:27)."
32.13: The blessing of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is peace, as it is said, "G-d shall bless his people with peace (Psalms 29:11)."
32.14: And after the 120 elders, and among them some prophets, established the prayer in order, what did Shimon HaPakuli order?
32.15: They forgot the [order], and he returned and ordered them.
32.16: Farther than these [nineteen blessings], it is forbidden to praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, for Rabbi Elazar said,
32.17: What is the meaning of the verse, "He who recites the great doings of G-d shall recite all his praises (Psalms 106:2)"? To whom is it befitting to recite [all] the great doings of G-d? To someone who can say all his praises [which are infinite].
32.18: Rabba the grandson of Chana said, "Rabbi Yochanan said,
32.19: 'He who praises G-d too much is uprooted from the world, as it is said,
32.20: 'Shall it be told Him that I would speak? Or should a man wish that he were swallowed up (Job 37:20)?'
32.21: Rabbi Yehuda of Kefar Gevuria, or some say of Kefar Gibor Chayil, expounded,
32.22: "What is the meaning of the verse, 'For you, silence is praise (Psalms 65:2)'? Silence is a cure for everything."
32.23: When Rav Dimi came [from Israel], he said,
32.25: 'A word is worth a Sela, silence two.
32.26: (Mishnah:) If he read it by heart, he has not fulfilled his obligation.
32.27: (Gemara:) From where do we know this?
32.29: "This is learnt from the word Zechirah, which appears in two places. It is stated here [in the Megillah] 'And these days are remembered', and it is stated there (Exodus 17:14) 'Write this as a remembrance in the book.' Just as there, where the word 'remember' means in a book, so too here, it means that we 'remember...these days' from a book."
32.30: But how do we know that 'remember' means to read it out loud?
32.31: Perhaps it refers to the general study [of the Megillah.]?
32.32: You should not think thus (as it says)
32.33: "Remember" (Devarim 25:17): It could mean in your heart,
32.34: but then it goes on "do not forget" (ibid. vv. 19) - and the heart does forget! Rather, I must be fulfilling "remember" with the mouth [by recitation.]:
32.35: [MISHNA:] "If he read it in Aramaic, he did not fulfill is obligation..."
32.37: If the scroll is written in Hebrew, and the reader reads in Aramaic, this is by heart! [which was forbidden previously.]
32.38: Therefore, here, the case must be that it was written in Aramaic and it was read in Aramaic.
32.39: [MISHNA:] "But he may read in a foreign language to a foreigner."
32.40: Had we not said [previously in the Mishna] that to read in any [other] language was not permissible?
32.42: [Here, we are dealing with] the Greek language.
32.44: If the scroll was written in Hebrew block letters, and the reader read in Greek, he is reading by heart!
32.45: Said R' Acha son of R' Eliezer:
32.46: The scroll was also written in Greek.
32.47: R' Acha son of R' Eliezer also said:
32.48: From where do we see that the Holy One, Blessed Be He, called Jacob "El"?
32.49: As it says (Genesis 33:20): "And he called it 'El Elohei Yisrael'.
32.50: Had Jacob called the altar [from the verses] "El", it should have read "And Jacob called" [instead of "he"]. Rather, it means "And he called Jacob 'El'." Who called him this? "'Elohei Yisrael' ['God of Israel']."
32.51: We raise a question [from a Braita:]
32.52: "If he read it in Giftian, Hebrew, Elamite, Medite, or Greek, he did not fulfill his obligation."
32.53: [That is if he did not understand the language. Rav and Shmuel discuss one who knows Greek, as in] these examples of reading
32.54: "in Giftian to Giftians, Hebrew to Hebrews, Elamite to Elamites, or Greek to Greeks, he has fulfilled his obligation."
32.55: If so, then why did Rav and Shmuel establish that the "foreign language" was Greek,
32.56: if the same applies to every language?
32.57: (Rather, the Mishna follows the Braita, and) Rav and Samuel say that Greek is good for all peoples. ...
32.58: Did Rav and Shmuel really say
32.59: that Greek is good for all?
32.60: Does it not teach [in the Braita:] "Greek to Greeks" - and the word "Greeks" comes to exclude all other nations?
32.61: It is as Raban Shimon ben Gamliel taught [in a Mishna:] "Raban Shimon ben Gamliel says:
32.62: [holy] Books may not be written [in any other language] save for Greek. [and cannot be maftir anyone an obligation, save for Greek.]"
32.63: Rav and Shmuel hold like this.
32.64: If so, then they should have said [instead of "You may read in Greek"] "The law is in accordance with Raban Shimon son of Gamliel."
32.65: No, Greek must be explicitly taught in the case of Megillah, where it says "as it is written [in this book in Hebrew.]"
32.66: [MISHNA:] "A foreigner who heard it in Hebrew has fulfilled his obligation." But he doesn't understand what is being said!
32.67: Rather, one has fulfilled his obligation even without understanding, like women and country bumpkins.
32.68: Ravina strongly disagreed with this answer, saying:
32.69: "And do we know the meaning of ha-achashteranim benei ha-ramachim?
32.70: But all the same we perform the Mitzvah of reading the Megillah and proclaiming the miracle. So they too perform the Mitzvah of reading the Megillah and proclaiming the miracle."
32.71: [MISHNA:] "If he read it with seirugin, he has fulfilled his obligation."
32.72: The Rabbis did not know what seirugin was. Then, one day, they heard the maid of Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi's house say to the Rabbis who would come into the house at intervals.
32.73: "How long will you come in seirugin seirugin?"
32.74: The Rabbis did not know what chaluglugot was. Then, one day, they heard the maid of Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi's house on seeing a man peeling portulaks, say to him, "How long will you be peeling your chaluglugoth?"
32.75: The Rabbis did not know what (Proverbs 4:8)"Salsalah, vtiromemeca" was.
32.76: Then, one day, they heard the maid of Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi's house on seeing a man curling his hair, say to him,
32.77: "How long will you be mesalsel your hair?"
32.78: The Rabbis did not know what (Psalms 55:23) "Throw unto God yahevcha" was,
32.79: until Rabah bar bar Chana said:
32.80: "One time, I was walking with an Arab and I was carrying a load. He told me
32.81: take your yehav and put it on one of the camels."
32.82: The Rabbis did not know what (Isaiah 14:23) "Ve'ta'ateia bemata'atea of destruction" meant. Then, one day, they heard the maid of Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi's house tell her friend,
32.83: "Take your ta'atea and sweep the house."
32.85: "If he read it in intervals, he fulfilled his obligation."

33.0: if with omissions, he has not fulfilled it.
33.1: R. Muna said in the name of R. Judah:
33.2: Even with breaks, if he stops long enough to finish the whole of it, he must go back to the beginning.
33.4: The halakhah is according to R. Muna in the name of R. Judah.
33.6: [When it says] “long enough to finish the whole of it” does it mean from where he is to the end, or from the beginning to the end?
33.8: It means from the beginning to the end, for otherwise there would be no fixed standard.
33.9: Abba said in the name of R. Jeremiah b. Abba who said it in the name of Rav:
33.10: The halakhah accords with R. Muna. And Shmuel said:
33.11: The halakhah does not accord with R. Muna.
33.12: This is the version taught in Sura.
33.13: In Pumbedita the following version was taught:
33.14: R. Kahana said in the name of Rav:
33.15: The halakhah accords with R. Muna, but Shmuel said
33.16: that the halakhah does not accord with R. Muna.
33.17: R. Bibi reverses the statement, [making] Rav say that
33.18: the halakhah does not accord with R. Muna and Shmuel say
33.19: that it does accord with R. Muna.
33.21: Accept the version of R. Bibi, since it is Shmuel who rules according to the view of a minority opinion,
33.23: ‘If a woman was waiting for the yavam [to make his decision], and a [younger] brother of his betrothed her sister, in the name of R. Judah b. Batera they said:
33.24: They say to him, Wait till your elder brother acts [one way or the other];
33.26: The halakhah accords with R. Judah b. Batera.
33.28: If the scribe had omitted letters or verses and the reader read them like the translator when he is translating, he has fulfilled his obligation.
33.30: If letters in it [the scroll] are partially rubbed out or torn, if they are still legible, it may be used, but otherwise it may not be used.
33.32: one statement refers to all of it, the other to part of it.

33.49: that all of it [must be recited], and even according to the one who says that it is sufficient [to recite] from "A Jew was" (Esther 2:5), it is necessary that the whole should be [already] written?

33.65: The whole Torah could be written by you by heart, but the Sages have ruled:

33.70: as it has been taught: R. Jeremiah says in the name of our Teacher:

34.4: From where do we know this?

34.6: MISHANH: A resident of a town who has gone to a walled city or a resident of a walled city who has gone to a town, if he is to return to his own place he reads according to the rule of his own place, and if not reads with them.

34.9: all of it. Rabbi Judah says:
34.14: They taught this only if he intends to return on the night of the fourteenth; but if he does not mean to return on the night of the fourteenth, he reads with the rest.
34.16: From where do I derive this ruling? As it is written, “Therefore do the Jews of the villages who dwell in the unwalled towns” (Esther 9:19). Since it is written, “the Jews of the villages” why did it need to write, “who dwell in the unwalled towns”?
34.18: one who is a villager for one day is called a villager.
34.19: We have proved this for a villager. How do we know that it applies also to inhabitants of walled towns?
34.20: It is reasonable: If a villager of one day is called a villager, a walled-city-dweller of one day is called a walled-city-dweller.
34.22: A villager who has gone to a town reads with the rest in any case.
34.24: He should read at the same time as the townspeople — and it is the Rabbis who made a concession to the villagers so that they might supply food and drink to their brothers in the large cities.
34.25: Now this applies only so long as they are in their own place, but when they are in the town, they must read like the townspeople.
34.27: If a resident of a walled city went to a town, in any case he reads according to the custom of his own place.
34.28: “A resident of a walled city” would you really think?
34.29: His rule depends on whether he means to return.
34.31: [Rava could respond]: But have you emended the [baraita] in any case.
34.34: From where does he read the Megillah etc.
34.35: It has been taught: R. Shimon b. Yohai says:
34.38: All these rabbis derived their rule from the same verse:
34.39: “Then Esther the queen and Mordecai the Jew wrote all the acts of power” (9:29).
34.40: He who says the whole Megillah, this refers to the power of Ahashverosh; he who says from “There was a Jew,” he power of Mordecai; he who says from “After these things” the power of Haman; and he who says, from “On that night” the power of the miracle.
34.42: They derived it from here: “Of what they saw in that matter and of what came upon them” (9:26). He who says that the whole of it must be read [interprets thus]: What did Ahashverosh see to make him use the vessels of the Temple? “In that matter”, in that he reckoned seventy years and they had not yet been redeemed;
34.43: “And what came upon them?” That he killed Vashti. He who says that it should be read from “There was a Jew” [interprets thus]: What had Mordecai seen that he provoked Haman? “In that matter”, that he made himself an object of idolatry. “And what came upon them”? That a miracle occurred.
34.44: He who says that it is to be read from “After these things,” [interprets thus]: What did Haman see to make him provoke all the Jews? “In that matter”, that Mordecai did not bow down or prostrate himself; “And what came upon him”? They hung him and his sons on the tree. He who says that it is to be read from “On that night” interprets thus: What did Ahashverosh see to make him order them to bring the Chronicles? “In that matter” that Esther invited Haman with him. “And what came upon them”? A miracle occurred.
34.45: R. Helbo said in the name of R. Hama b. Guria, who said it in the name of Rav:
34.46: The halakhah follows the one who says that the whole of it must be read;
34.47: and even according to the one who says that it need be read only from “There was a Jew” it must all be written.
34.48: Hama b. Guria said in the name of Rav:

34.50: This is only on condition that they are evenly spaced.

34.52: If one reads from a Megillah written among the rest of the Writings, he has not fulfilled his obligation.

34.55: Levi b. Samuel was reading before R. Judah in a Megillah

35.0: which was written among the Writings.

35.13: R. Hiyya b. Abba also said in the name of R. Yohanan:
35.14: What is the meaning of what is written, And on them was written according to all the words which the Lord spoke with you in the Mount” (Deuteronomy 9:10)? It teaches us that the Holy One, blessed be He, showed Moses the minute details of the Torah, and the minute details of the Scribes, and the innovations which would be introduced by the Scribes; and what are these? The reading of the Megillah.
35.15: All are valid to read the Megillah except a deaf person, an imbecile and a minor. Rabbi Judah validates a minor.
35.16: GEMARA. Who is the Tanna that holds that [even if] the deaf person has read, it does not count?
35.18: R. It is R. Yose, as we have learned:
35.19: One who read the Shema but doesn’t make it heard to his ears, he has fulfilled his obligation. R. Yose says that
35.20: he has not fulfilled his obligation.
35.21: But how do we know that [our Mishnah] follows R. Yose and even if the deaf person has read, it does not count?

35.24: But perhaps there is one rule for the one and another rule for the other?
35.25: Since it teaches in the final clause that
35.26: R. Judah validates a minor, we may conclude that the first clause does not state the opinion of R. Judah.
35.27: (But perhaps the whole of the Mishnah states the opinions of R. Judah? —
35.29: he should disqualify in the first and permit in the second?)
35.30: But perhaps the whole [of the Mishnah] is R. Judah, and he teaches of two kinds of minors, and the Mishnah is lacking and it should teach this:
35.31: All are qualified to read the Megillah, except a deaf man, an imbecile and a minor. What is this speaking of? Of a minor who is not old enough to be educated in the mitzvot. But a minor who is old enough to be educated in the mitzvot may read even ab initio, since R. Judah declares a minor qualified!
35.32: How then have you explained [the first clause of the Mishnah]? Like R. Judah and ex post facto.
35.33: Then that which was taught by R. Judah the son of R. Shimon b. Pazzi:
35.34: One who can speak but not hear may set aside terumah ab initio. Whose view is this?
35.35: If you say, R. Judah, he holds that this is only ex post facto, but not ab initio.
35.36: If you say R. Yose, he invalidates the action even ex post facto.
35.37: What then will you say? That it follows R. Judah, and that he allows it even ab initio?
35.38: What about this which has been taught:

36.7: “Which I command you this day upon your heart” according to the words follow the intention of the heart.

36.10: R. Judah declares a minor qualified.
36.13: When I was a young boy, I read it [the Megillah] in front of R. Tarfon and the elders in Lod.
36.15: Proof cannot be brought from the testimony of a minor.
36.16: It has been taught: Rabbi said:
36.17: When I was a young boy, I read it before R. Judah.

36.19: Why did they not say to him:
36.20: Proof cannot be brought from the testimony of a minor?
36.21: They gave one answer and then another.
36.22: First, they said, you were a boy and moreover,
36.23: even had you been an adult, proof cannot be brought from the very one who allows it.
36.24: Mishnah: They do not read the Megillah, nor circumcise, nor go to the mikveh, nor sprinkling [purificatory waters], and similarly a woman keeping day for day should not take a ritual bath until the sun has risen.
36.25: But if any of these things is done after dawn, it is valid.
36.26: Gemara. From where do we know this?
36.27: Because the verse says, “And these days should be remembered and kept” (Esther 9:28) by day, but not by night.
36.28: Shall we say that this is a refutation of R. Joshua b. Levi;
36.29: for R. Joshua b. Levi said:
36.30: One must read the Megillah by night and a second time by day?
36.31: When the mishnah taught it, it referred to the day.
36.33: As it is written, “And on the eighth day he shall be circumcised” (Leviticus 12:3).
36.34: Neither should one immerse [in a mikveh] nor sprinkle. As it is written, “And the clean person shall sprinkle on the unclean . . . And on the seventh day” (Numbers 19:19) and immersing is compared to sprinkling.
36.35: And similarly a woman keeping day for day should not immerse until the sun has risen.
36.37: Why should a woman keeping day for day be different from all others who are obligated to immerse?
36.38: It is necessary, lest you think that she should be the same as the first observation of one who had a genital discharge, and the first observation of one who had a genital discharge has been compared to one who had a seminal issue, as it is written, “This is the law of him that has had a genital discharge (zav) and of him from whom the flow of seed has gone out.” (Leviticus 15:32) Just as one with a seminal issue immerses during the day, so too this one immerses on the same day.
36.39: This woman, however, cannot immerse on that day, because it is written, “All the days of her discharge she shall be as in the days of her menstrual impurity”; (Leviticus 15:26) so [you might say], by night at least she might keep watch for a short time and then immerse;
36.40: therefore we are told that [she must not do this],
36.41: because she requires to count [day for day];

37.0: and counting must be by day.
37.1: If any of these things is done after dawn has appeared, it is valid.
37.2: From where is this rule derived?
37.4: For the verse says, “And God called the light day” something which gradually becomes light he called day.
37.5: But according to this, [when it says] “And the darkness he called night” [are we to explain] that which gradually becomes dark he called night?
37.6: .Do we not hold that until the stars come out it is not night?
37.7: Rather R. Zera said: We derive it from here:
37.8: “And so we worked on; and half of them held the spears from the rising of the morning till the stars appeared” and it says,
37.9: “That in the night they may be a guard for us, and that we may work in the day” (Nehemiah 4:15-16). What is the point of the second quotation? —
37.10: You might say that from the time of the first rising of the dawn it is not yet day, though from the time the sun begins to set it is already night and they rose early and stopped work late.Therefore come and hear: ” That in the night they may be a guard for us, and that we may work in the day.”
37.11: The whole day is a valid time for     reading the Megillah; reciting Hallel; for the blowing of the shofar; for taking up the lulav; for the Musaf prayer; for Musaf sacrifices; for confession over the oxen; for the confession over the tithe; for the confession of sins on Yom HaKippurim; for laying on of hands; for slaughtering [the sacrifices]; for waving [them]; for bringing near [the vessel with the minhah-offering to the altar]; for taking a handful; for placing it on the fire; for pinching off [the head of a bird-offering]; for receiving the blood [in a vessel]; for sprinkling [the blood on the altar]; for making the sotah drink [the bitter waters]; for breaking the neck of the heifer; and for purifying the metzora.
37.12: The whole night is valid for reaping the Omer and for burning fat and limbs [on the altar].
37.14: any matter whose commandment is during the day, is valid all day
37.15: and any matter whose commandment is at night is valid all night.
37.16: Gemara. From where do we know this? Because the verse says, “And these days shall be mentioned and kept” (Esther 9:28).
37.17: For reading the Hallel: As it is written, “From the rising of the sun to its going down” (Psalms 113:3). R. Joseph says: Because it is written,
37.18: “This is the day which the Lord has made” (Psalms 118:24). For the taking of the lulav: As it is written, “And you shall take for yourself on the first day” (Leviticus 23:40).
37.19: For the blowing of the shofar, as it is written, “It is a day of blasting for you” (Numbers 29:1).
37.20: For the additional sacrifices, as it is written, “Each on its own day” (Leviticus 23:37).
37.21: And for the musaf prayer: Because the rabbis made them like the additional sacrifices. And for the confession made over the oxen. For the “atonement” mentioned here is derived from the “atonement” mentioned in the context of Yom Kippur, as it has been taught in reference to Yom Kippur:
37.22: “And he shall make atonement for himself and for his house” (Leviticus 16:6)
37.23: the text speaks of atonement made by words. And atonement is by day, as it is written, “For on this day shall atonement be made for you” (Leviticus 16:30). And for the confession made over the tithe: As it is written, “And you shall say before the Lord your God, I have removed the sacred things from my house” (Deuteronomy 26:13), and in an adjacent context it says, “This day the Lord your God commands you” (26:16). And for waving: as it is written, “And on the day when you wave the sheaf” (Leviticus 23:12).
37.24: And for bringing near, for it is compared to waving, as it is written, “And the priest shall take the minhah offering of jealousy out of the woman’s hand, and shall wave the meal-offering . . . And bring it near [to the altar]” (Numbers 5:25).
37.25: And for pinching and for taking a handful and for burning and for sprinkling, as it is written, “On the day that He commanded the children of Israel [to present their offerings]” (Leviticus 7:35). And for making the sotah drink:
37.26: This is derived from the word “Torah” “Torah”. It is written here, “And the priest shall do to her all this Torah” (Numbers 5:30), and it is written elsewhere, “According to the Torah which they teach you and according to the judgement” (Deuteronomy 17:11):

38.0: just as judgement is by day, so here it must be by day.
38.1: And for breaking the neck of the heifer. In the school of R. Yannai they said:

38.9: To include the arrangement of the cup and the removal of the cups, and like R. Yose,
38.10: as it has been taught: R. Yose says:

38.17: May we return to you “One who reads out of order.”

38.27: on any day which has a musaf and is not a festival four read.
38.29: On Yom Hakippurim six. On Shabbat seven;

38.42: and that is what we have learned that
38.43: "When Rabban Gamaliel died, the honor of Torah was nullified."

39.20: Blessed are You, O Lord our God, king of the universe, [the God] who fought our fight and judged our judgment and avenged our vengeance and punished our adversaries for us and paid back retribution on all the enemies of our lives.
